|''Keen Hearing:'' The Bushyasta has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.|>|>|>|>|>|
|''Charge:'' If the Bushyasta has moved at least 20 ft straight towards a creature and then hits it with a Ram attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a DC 12 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.|>|>|>|>|>|
|font-size: 18px;border-bottom:1px solid #7A200D;font-variant:small-caps;color:#7A200D;Actions|>|>|>|>|>|
|''Multiattack.'' The Bushyasta makes two attacks.|>|>|>|>|>|
|''Ram.''  //Melee Weapon Attack:// +6 to hit, reach 10 ft, one target.  //Hit:// 11 (1d6 +3) bludgeoning  damage.|>|>|>|>|>|
|''Claw.''  //Melee Weapon Attack:// +6 to hit, reach 10 ft, one target.  //Hit:// 11 (2d6 +4) slashing  damage.|>|>|>|>|>|
[>img[images/locations/caldoria/caldoria.jpg]]
Caldoria was a continent that existed up until [[The Second Desecration]], comprised mainly of reclusive [[Dragonborn]] and their [[Tabaxi]] slaves.  Before the events of [[The Second Desecration]], the [[Dragonborn]] elders who comprised [[The Conclave Of Voices]] witnessed a foul taint spreading across [[Asha]] - a world ending calamity that caused them to protect [[Caldoria]] from destruction. Using powerful [[Artifice]] long forgotten, they submerged their major cities beneath the ocean where they believed the touch of [[Desecration]] could not reach.  [[Dragonborn]] civilization lived undisturbed and isolated for countless years under magical domes that kept the dark cold water at bay - until [[The Lifting]] in 1021 [[AAP]] where the island cities returned to the surface of the ocean.

The Island Cities of Caldoria form into a government known as [[The Tyrnan Accord]], and include the islands of [[Anmanu]], [[Kunusut]], [[Annofu]], [[Sasu]], [[Ekru]], [[Nekkhapata]], and [[Ansapis]].  Each of the islands with the exception of [[Kunusut]] floats high above in the sky propelled by ancient [[Magic]].

[[The Guardian Of Caldoria]] is a large lobster shaped leviathan that lives beneath the ocean surrounding the islands.  It is ancient in design and construction - a mix of metal and flesh similar to the process undergone by [[The Children Of The Forge]]

| [img[images/locations/caldoria/Annofu-icon.jpg][Annofu]] <br>[[Annofu]] |[[Annofu]] is the highest in the sky, sitting at the cloud layer which gives it the nickname of "The Isle In The Clouds".  It is actually a collection of smaller fragments of island, which due to the cloud layer collect water and rain it down upon the other islands; creating a consistent stream of fresh water supply.  Few actually live here, as the thin air makes it less hospitable to those of weaker constitution. |
| [img[images/locations/caldoria/anmanu-icon.jpg][Anmanu]] <br>[[Anmanu]] |[[Anmanu]] is the seat of power for [[Dragonborn]] society, and floats high in the sky above all but the isle of [[Annofu]].  It is where [[The Hall Of Thrones]] is found, where [[The Conclave Of Voices]] rule over the Caldorian population.  [[The House Of The Eternal]] can also be found here, where some [[Dragonborn]] practice an ancient form of [[Artifice]] that augments their own bodies. |
| [img[images/locations/caldoria/Ekru-icon.jpg][Ekru]] <br>[[Ekru]] |[[Ekru]] is a floating paradise, second largest of the floating islands, celebrated for its stunning views and lush and still untamed rain forests.  It has a much more secluded, natural feel compared to the other islands. |
| [img[images/locations/caldoria/ansapis-icon.jpg][Ansapid]] <br>[[Ansapis]] |[[Ansapis]] is a holy city, and the religious center of Caldoria.  It is here that [[The Faith Of The Ten]] has its seat of power in [[The Pyramid Of Tyrnus]].  Since Caldoria's return to the surface of [[Asha]], [[Ansapis]] has been the slowest to adopt new customs and ways; its citizens clinging firm to old traditions and customs. |
| [img[images/locations/caldoria/nekkhapata-icon.jpg][Nekkhapata]] <br>[[Nekkhapata]] |[[Nekkhapata]] is the largest island, rich in mountains and minerals.  It has a diverse ecosystem ranging from rainforests to deserts, and the main city is famous for being partially underground. |
| [img[images/locations/caldoria/Sasu-icon.jpg][Sasu]] <br>[[Sasu]] |[[Sasu]] is also known as the "Forbidden Island", left untouched by the decree of [[The Conclave Of Voices]] centuries ago.  The island is filled with relics of [[The First Age]], preserved for countless millennia.  No [[Dragonborn]] are permitted to live here, and it stands as a grave and monument to long lost [[History]]. |
| [img[images/locations/caldoria/kunusut-icon.jpg][Kunusut]] <br>[[Kunusut]] |[[Kunusut]] is the only island of Caldoria that still floats upon the ocean.  It is an overcrowded island, filled to the brim with former [[Tabaxi]] slaves. The city is lawless and untamed, a sprawl of urban chaos that matches the haphazard architecture and pace of living. |
[>img[images/characters/kellos/the-keep/deepwater/the-magian-imperium/calistra-galdmoore.jpg]]
[[Magister]] Calistra Galdmoore (997 [[AAP]] - current) is a prominent member of [[The Magian Imperium]], known as much for her ambition as for her connection to [[The Gilded Compass]] (a wealthy merchant cartel).  Born into a wealthy merchant family, Calistra has turned her membership in the organization into a powerful tool for expanding her family’s influence. Though her [[Magical Abilities|Wizardry]] are limited to rudimentary [[Charms]], her charisma and cunning have allowed her to dominate the political and economic spheres of [[The Viridian Empire]].

Calistra was born into [[The Galdmoore Family|The Gilded Compass]], whose vast trade empire spans much of [[The Viridian Empire's|The Viridian Empire]] ports and markets. They trade under the name and banner of [[The Gilded Compass]], and have become one of the most influential merchant companies in [[The Empire|The Viridian Empire]].  From a young age, she was groomed to take her place as a key player in [[the family’s business ventures|The Gilded Compass]]. However, Calistra’s ambitions extended far beyond the merchant’s ledger. She saw in [[The Magian Imperium]] an opportunity to gain the social prestige that her merchant lineage could not provide.

In a bold move, Calistra secured her membership in [[The Magian Imperium]] by paying an unprecedented sum, effectively buying her way into the ranks. Her wealth ensured her swift acceptance, but her position was met with derision by more traditional members of [[the organization|The Magian Imperium]]. Undeterred, Calistra used her new title to solidify her family’s influence in [[The Empire’s|The Viridian Empire]] aristocratic circles.

As a member of [[The Magian Imperium]], [[Magister]] Calistra’s contributions to the [[Arcane Arts|Wizardry]] are negligible. Her magical repertoire consists of basic [[Charms]], which she uses primarily for decorative purposes or minor trade advantages. Despite this, she insists on being addressed as an expert in the [[Arcane]], a claim that few dare challenge due to her political clout.

Calistra’s true focus lies in leveraging her position to expand [[The Gilded Compass]].  She has used her influence as the [[Magister]] of [[The Department of Magical Transportation]] to secure lucrative trade contracts, intimidate competitors, and gain access to exclusive markets. Her title grants her entry into high society, where she forges alliances that benefit her family’s interests.

[[Magister]] Calistra is a force to be reckoned with. Though young, her lust for power is unrivaled, and she approaches every interaction with calculated precision. She exudes confidence and charm, masking a ruthless determination that often catches her rivals off guard. Her critics accuse her of embodying the worst excesses of [[The Magian Imperium]] , prioritizing personal gain over the organization’s mission to advance the arcane arts.
|Governor:|ruled by a council of 5 [[Patriars|Patriar]].|
|Population:|30,000|
|Fortifications:|None.|
|Law:|There are about 1000 men in the militia.  In times of war they can muster 2000+.|
|Resources:|Known for it's soaps and inks|

!Description
Candlekeep is known by several names, one of which is "The Floating City" in [[The Polité Of Bronze]].  This is due to the fact that the city consists of over 100 small islands connected by numerous canals and bridges.  Some of the buildings are built upon wooden platforms that are supported by stakes driven underwater to reinforce the construction.  There are tensions between the local inhabitants and a large group of refugees from [[Caldoria]] that are comprised of [[Tabaxi]].  The [[Tabaxi]] do not know the language and are poor, surviving by roaming the streets and living within dark alleys.

!Social Customs
* [[Panathenaea]] - is celebrated each year to honor the harvest and [[Umwe]].  The local [[Sorcerer|Sorcery]] [[Endymion Traxigor]] has elevated the holiday by offering trinkets to the locals in place of animal sacrifice.  This holiday is held above all others within the city of Candlekeep.

!Notable Characters and Groups
| [>img[images/characters/amon/bronze/anders-quinticius-solmar-portrait.jpg]] <br>[[Anders Quinticius Solmar]] |[[Anders Quinticius Solmar]] is a the richest [[Patriar]] within the city.  His family moved from [[Heliopolis]] two generations ago.  [[Anders|Anders Quinticius Solmar]] is the sole surviving heir to his family's fortune.  He often carries a cane that hides a thin Rapier.  He he betrothed to [[Carmila Volkos]], a marriage of convenience rather than love.  He has an air of formality about him that causes others around him to be formal as well.  He owns the largest fleet of shipping and fishing vessels within [[The Risen Reef]].  An [[Elvish|Elf]] manservant named [[Driane'eire]] served his family for generations.  But during [[Panathenaea]] in 1025 [[AAP]], the [[Draugaira]] [[Elf]] murdered three members of [[The Remnant]] and was seen no more.|
| [>img[images/characters/amon/bronze/carmila-volkos-portrait.jpg]] <br>[[Carmila Volkos]] |[[Carmila Volkos]] is the wife of [[Anders Quinticius Solmar]] and the daughter of [[Eliander Volkos]], a rich [[Patriar]] from [[Heliopolis]].  She is beautiful, slender, and skilled at playing a shy innocent girl who needs others for support.  In truth, she is cunning, manipulative, and lusts for power and control.  [[Carmila Volkos]] likes to do what she wants, when she wants - and knows she can always wriggle away from trouble with her looks, her status, or her money.  [[Blood Magic]] intrigues her, although she is careful in it's use as she knows it may damage her greatest asset: her appearance.|
| [>img[images/characters/amon/bronze/endymion-traxigor-portrait.jpg]] <br>[[Endymion Traxigor]] |__[[Endymion Traxigor]]__ is a local eccentric [[Sorcerer|Sorcery]] that lives in a small and simple hut within [[The Candlekeep Prominade]].  He can be seen roaming the town causing minor mischief with his servant, [[Avidar]].  He is adored by the townsfolk as much as he is tolerated.  While [[Endymion Traxigor]] often causes trouble, his heart is in the right place and he means well.  His full power in [[Magic]] is unknown, but it must be significant if he has permanently transformed himself into the body of a [[Beaver]].|
| [>img[images/characters/amon/bronze/vibius-castinus-portrait.jpg]] <br>[[Vibius Castinus]] |[[Vibius Castinus]] is a minor [[Patriar]] within the city.  He makes his riches off of the manufacture and distribution of soap.  He is a nemesis of [[Endymion Traxigor]], who he dislikes as the [[Beaver]] often gets his hair in his soap products.  [[Endymion Traxigor]] is unaware that [[Vibius Castinus]] dislikes him so - and often speaks fondly of their friendship. [[Vibius Castinus]] is a large man that always smells of lavender and sweet fragrance. |

!Places Of Interest
* [[The Candlekeep Prominade]] - a woodland park in the center of the city that many go to for relaxation.  A small stream runs through the area and is dammed up by [[Endymion Traxigor]] who has a small home inside the simple dam.  Most locals avoid his house, but enjoy their time in [[the park|The Candlekeep Prominade]].
* [[The Argyris Forrest]] - there is not much known about [[The Argyris Forrest]], as once inside the tangled woodland you find yourself lost before emerging from the place you entered void of memory.  Everyone knows to stay away, as ancient [[Magic]] guards the Forrest.
* [[The Seminarcana]] - is a towering library fortress that stands on a crag overlooking [[The Risen Reef]].  It contains a large sum of knowledge collected and curated by individuals known as [[The Affirmed]].  They live and work within the library, carefully tending to the knowledge within.  Those who do not live within the city often misinterpret [[The Seminarcana]] as "The Candlekeep", when Candlekeep is actually the name of the city in which it resides.  The symbol of the library is a castle emblazoned over a flame.  Entry is restricted and those that are let in are required to give a book for entry.
* [[The Short Gentleman]] - is a modest inn with the [[Dwarf]] [[Gerkyl Jadebraid]] as proprietor.  Despite the modest furnishings, he runs the place with great demeanor and class, treating all that arrive as [[Patriar]].
[>img[images/characters/amon/bronze/carmila-volkos.jpg]]
Carmila Volkos (1000 [[AAP]] - Current) is the wife of [[Anders Quinticius Solmar]] and the daughter of [[Eliander Volkos]], a rich [[Patriar]] from the city of [[Heliopolis]]. She is beautiful, slender, and skilled at playing a shy innocent girl who needs others for support. In truth, she is cunning, manipulative, and lusts for power and control. [[Carmila Volkos]] likes to do what she wants, when she wants - and knows she can always wriggle away from trouble with her looks, her status, or her money. [[Blood Magic]] intrigues her, although she is careful in it's use as she knows it may damage her greatest asset: her appearance.

!Personality
Carmila Volkos is fiercely protective of her position and reputation, and understands how fragile it can be.  She puts on an appearance in which she lives a storybook life, throwing parties and catering to the poorest of the [[Patriar]].  Secretly, she is disgusted by the people of [[Candlekeep]], thinking them small and backwater compared to her home in [[Heliopolis]].  Carmila is popular, and others often overlook her seemingly innocent disrespect which she cunningly interjects into conversations for her own amusement.  She is fixated on being the center of attention, and has a flair for dramatics.

!A Marriage Of Convenience
She married [[Anders Quinticius Solmar]] not for love, but for convenience.  As he is the richest [[Patriar]] of [[Candlekeep]], his wealth and position are able to sustain her lavish lifestyle.  Carmila doesn't dislike [[Anders|Anders Quinticius Solmar]], and even finds his gentleness charming on rare occasions; warming up to his generous personality.
[>img[images/bestiary/carrion-crawler.jpg]]

Carrion Crawlers resemble large pale yellow or green centipedes, roughly the size of a grown man.  They possess eight tentacles surrounding their toothy maw, which upon contact with skin cause a temporary paralysis.  They primarily feed off of dead or rotting corpses, which gives them their name.  They hunt through a keen sense of smell, despite the rotten stench they secrete from their mouth and skin.  Carrion Crawlers lay their eggs in piles of waste, which hatch in the hundreds and quickly consume one another, limiting the suitability of the offspring.
[>img[images/characters/ruje/tszanthus/cassee-dannell.jpg]]
//was a Non Player Character guest played by [[Brian Disbrow]] and [[Nick Prather]]//

[[Doctor]] Cassee Dannell (998 [[AAP]] / 1240 [[Hassomir]] - Current) is a somewhat enigmatic figure in the world of academia in the city of [[Tszanthus]] on the continent of [[Ruje]].  From a young age, she displayed an insatiable curiosity about the world and its many enigmas.  Growing up in the bustling city of [[Tszanthus]], Cassee was drawn to the city's rich history and diverse cultures.  Her academic journey began as a student of the prestigious [[Baldarrain University]] where she studied the mysterious and elusive field of anthropology and archeology.  While she showed a tremendous amount of talent, it soon became clear that Cassee's approach to her chosen field was far from conventional.

!Guided By Unconventional Wisdom
Cassee found herself under the tutelage of the brilliant [[Doctor]] [[Anbrosio Abanto]], who was notorious for his obsession with proving the fable of the lost city of [[Azlant]].  While [[Doctor]] [[Abanto|Anbrosio Abanto]] was cruel to his students, Cassee was able to persevere and assist in some key research that provided clues to a precursor culture that led credence to the [[Azlant]] mythos.  This unconventional path led her to explore other hidden mysteries and engage in fringe hypotheses that blurred the lines of fairy tale and reality.

!Fringe Theories
''The Ethereal Veil'' - Cassee delved into the concept of an ethereal veil that separates the living world from the realm of spirits and the afterlife.  She theorized that this veil was not impenetrable and that spirits of the deceased could sometimes breach it, crossing into the world of the living.  Cassee's research involved studying accounts of ghostly encounters and near death experiences.  She has since abandoned this research and line of thinking.

''The Hidden Societies Of The Undercity'' - Fascinated by the [[Undercity]] of [[Tszanthus]], Cassee hypothesized that vast cultures existed beneath the city.  Hidden societies, ancient cults, and forgotten rituals taking place beneath the bustling streets.

''Extraterrestrial Influences'' - Cassee believes that early civilizations of [[Asha]] had contact with extraterrestial beings, suggesting the origins of [[Human]] culture may have began out in the stars.
[>img[images/bestiary/catoblepas.jpg]]
The Catoblepas is native to the vile swamplands of [[Caldoria]].  It is a large lumbering beast resembling a cross between a [[Yak]], [[Buffalo]] or [[Warthog]] found in other parts of [[Asha]].  It is content in lazily wallowing in its marshy home, munching on vegetation and carrion.  It is roughly the size of two [[Horses|Horse]] with a bloated hairy body like a [[Buffalo]].  It has a long neck like a [[Giraffe]] and a head like a [[Warthog]] with yellowed tusks.

The [[Dragonborn]] of [[Caldoria]] have domesticated the creatures.  A dangerous proposition since Catoblepas have a noxious perpetual scent of death that can only be removed if it is regularly bathed.  The [[Dragonborn]] also blind the animal for their gaze causes necrotic damage.  This process of blinding the creature causes the domesticated Catoblepas to have cloudy milk colored eyes.  They use the creatures as beasts of burden to pull wagons and plow fields.
Cavorite is an ore, found primarily in the region of [[Kellos]] near the city of [[Hagen]].  Using acid, it can be refined into [[Residuum]], which is useful in magical [[Enchantment]].

It is often confused with opal, as it is similar in color and texture.  It is distinguishable by its orange and yellow streaks that look like veins.

!Discovery
The [[Dwarf]] [[Wizard|Wizardry]] [[Cavor Firebelly]] is rumored to be the discoverer of Cavorite and the process of refining it into [[Residuum]], however there is no record of his existence and he is lost to time.  There are multiple versions of the story by which he created [[Residuum]]; most note that his discovery was an accident.
[>img[images/characters/amon/caxton-loom.jpg]]

Caxton Loom (980 [[AAP]] - current) was a pirate of [[The Mummers]] within [[The Risen Reef]] of [[Amon]].  Known by the moniker "The Mongrel" due to his physicality.  Caxton was a [[Kell]] born in [[Kellos]] who found his way to [[The Risen Reef]] and joined [[The Mummers]] as a pirate.  His brutality was difficult to contain, and he was routinely chastised by [[The Salt King]] [[Garrad Stroud]] due to pushing the limits of the rules of [[The Mummers]].  In 1006 [[AAP]], Caxton was chastised for the final time; he killed [[Garrad Stroud]] and assumed the title of [[The Salt King]].  While [[Garrad Stroud]] was beloved like a grandfather to many in [[The Mummers]], Caxton saw him as weak and easily overpowered him.

As [[The Salt King]], Caxton Loom sought to abolish the code of [[The Mummers]]; he saw the rites of parley and the code of civility as antiquated.  Many of [[The Mummers]] took offense to these changes, and Caxton murdered them.  It was [[Rafail Kallides]] who eventually usurped him and returned [[The Mummers]] to their former glory.  After besting Caxton, [[Rafail Kallides]] used a [[Blood Magic]] ritual in 1010 [[AAP]] to remove Caxton's soul and place it into Caxton's son [[Whyenne Loom]] so as to ensure the child wouldn't grow up a tyrant like his father.  The husk of Caxton Loom served [[Rafail Kallides]] as his [[Zombie]] lapdog, loyal to him and as retribution for the damage he did to the culture of [[The Mummers]].  Runes tattooed across his face are remnants of the ritual which removed his [[Soul]].

In 1026 [[AAP]], Caxton's son [[Whyenne Loom]], bristling with the newfound powers of an [[Apotheon]] used his fledgling abilities to seek redemption within his father.  Seeing there was the potential for good inside of him, [[Whyenne|Whyenne Loom]] returned his soul and renounced his powers as an [[Apotheon]] such that he could spend the remaining days with Caxton and have the relationship they never were able to have; for Caxton was as terrible of a father in [[Whyenne's|Whyenne Loom]] youth as he was a [[Salt King]].  Together, they travel [[Asha]] and experience life with a newfound perspective.
Cenedriane ("Twilight Breeze" in [[Elvish]]) was a one of the most radiant cities in [[The Feywild]], seat of power and home to [[The Autumn Court]].  It was the site of the longest and most vicious battle with the [[Fomorians|Fomorian]], and has long since been abandoned and overtaken by wilderness.  The surrounding lands are dark twisted wilderness, haunted by terrible spirits.

The original city still stands as a cursed ruin.  At the city center, crystal towers stand empty and overgrown.  Creatures live in the hollowed out buildings.  Large shards of white stone buildings hang frozen within the air, where the cataclysm that destroyed the city left them.  [[Wild Magic]] surges are frequent, making it a dangerous place to visit.
[>img[images/bestiary/changeling.jpg]]
Changlings (also called shifters, vexlings, doubles, imitators, or pavrats) are shapeshifters found in [[The Feywild]] who can take the form of anyone or any beast they have encountered, provided it has a similar body mass.  In their natural form, they appear as a viscous orange liquid.  Once members of [[The Wild Folk]] of [[The Court Of Sun]], they were cursed into being [[Fell Folk|The Fell Folk]] and their connection to [[The Great Link]] was severed forever.

!Biology
Changelings possess the ability to morph into nearly anything given the right amount of skill and time: inanimate objects such as rocks or trees, animals and even sentient beings such as [[Humans|Human]].  In rare cases, advanced Changelings have demonstrated the ability to morph into gaseous elements and even fire.  They can copy the appearance of creatures so precisely that they acquire all physical features (including voice).  However, skills, mindset, and characteristic behaviors do not transfer.  Changelings are expert mimics and can instinctively pick up these traits through previous insightful observation.  Additionally, Changelings can transform fragments of their bodies into clothes or equipment, such as a sword or lute.  

Their abilities have some limitations, however: shapeshifting is only possible only if they avoid contact with silver, and any item created from their body transforms into an inert orange gelatinous mass if it loses contact with the rest of a Changeling.  This mass can be reabsorbed.

Changelings cannot maintain any chosen form indefinitely and must return to their natural gelatinous state every 16-18 hours in a dormant rest.  If a Changeling does not return to its natural state, its shifted state will begin to crumble and flake like drying clay.  Sometimes it appears that the Changeling slowly melts rather than crumbles.

Changelings can assume the forms of both male and female humanoids. The majority of Changelings appear to favor either a male or female form, even when impersonating individual solids. It was unknown if this indicates a true biological gender or gender identity, or is simply a matter of personal preference.

Changelings have no sense of smell or taste, and have no need to breathe or eat.  Even in humanoid forms, they do not need to take in sustenance, and can not absorb or break down food.

Changeling thoughts and emotions can not easily be read by [[Magic]].

!Psychology
Changeling society revolves around [[The Great Link]], a communal intermingling of Changelings in their natural liquid form.  While [[The Great Link]] was lost with the destruction of [[The Court Of Sun]], the genetic memory of this connection remains.  The union was often described as an experience of transcendence, a state of being where individual identity faded into collective unity.  Changelings prefer to think of themselves as a drop (the individual) in a larger ocean (what they call [[The Great Link]]).  A Changeling therefore, typically had little sense of individual identity.

While in [[The Great Link]], Changelings would have little sense of time or its individual self, merging seamlessly into the collective consciousness.  Here, thoughts and emotions from the community flowed freely and quickly.  This connection was so profound that many Changelings that experienced separation from [[The Great Link]] found it deeply unsettling.  Those who lived apart from their kind often sought out other Changelings to recreate a semblance of unity.

Shapeshifting provided Changelings with a kind of physical empathy for other lifeforms, granting them deeper insight into the creatures they mimic.  However, most Changelings spent the majority of their existence immersed in [[The Great Link]], leaving them detached from the lives of other beings, content with the shared experiences brought to [[The Great Link]] from others of their kind who once disconnected.  [[The Great Link]] created a profound social order within Changeling society, and throughout their entire history, no Changeling had ever harmed another.  The very thought and idea was abhorrent.

!Loss Of The Great Link
[[The Great Link]], once the foundation of Changeling society and identity, is now lost to them.  This catastrophic severance left the Changelings isolated from one another, unable to experience the profound unity that had defined their existence for eons.  Without [[The Link|The Great Link]], Changelings were forced to grapple with a newfound individuality, a concept that many found alien and unsettling.  This loss created a deep yearning for connection, driving some to wander endlessly.

!Use In Goblin Magic and Fey Bargains
There are multiple cases of Changelings infants being swapped with [[Human]] infants, usually without the parent's knowledge.  The [[Human]] child is taken to [[The Feywild]] and in its place, a Changeling is left behind.  This new infant is a new perfect copy, although they may appear more otherworldly.  Changelings infants exhibit peculiar behaviors, often being more difficult, demanding, or troublesome than the [[Human]] child they replaced.  Often, this is in service to the [[Alderking|Llvarana]], harvesting [[Human]] memories in order to re-establish [[The Court Of Sun]].

If a child is suspected of being a Changeling, causing harm to it (removing a piece of its flesh), or harming it with silver is the fastest test.  It is also possible to attempt to catch it in its resting, gelatinous state.
The Cherubim are [[AstraKashira]] formed after the closing of [[The Divine Gate]] at the end of [[The Second Age]].  They have no living memory or experience with [[The Elysians|Elysian]], and have not known the embrace of [[Lucian]].  Unlike [[AstraKashira]] formed by [[Lucian]] herself, who long to hear from their creator, the Cherubim hear [[Lucian]] whisper in their ears the moment they awaken.

Cherubim are formed by the song of [[The Heavenly Chorus]].  It is the power of the [[Mortal Souls|Soul]] which comprise [[The Chorus|The Heavenly Chorus]] which sing the Cherubim into existence.  This is a very rare occurrence and beyond the comprehension of the [[AstraKashira]].  Seen as a blessing, the Cherubim are welcomed with open arms.  One [[AstraKashira]] feels bonded to the new Cherubim.  While the Cherubim enter the world fully formed and indistinguishable from other [[AstraKashira]] - the bond is similar to one of parent and child.  The [[AstraKashira]] cares for the Cherubim, protecting and nurturing them.
[>img[images/bestiary/famous/chester.jpg]]
Chester is a [[Mimic]] in the form of a treasure chest, who is kept as a pet by [[Salix Daelof]] at [[The Athenaeum]]; a school of [[Wizardry]] in [[Zylok]].  Chester has been trained to obey simple commands, and can appear friendly, but is still a wild creature at heart.  If Chester has not had his multiple meals a day, he gets cranky.
[>img[images/bestiary/ruje/chuul.jpg]]
A Chuul is a crustacean-like beast common to [[Ruje]].  There are multiple breeds of the animal that comes in a variety of shapes and sizes.  Domesticated Chuul are often used in place of [[Horse]] for hauling.  Their claws are large and powerful enough to snap a man's arm, however tame Chuul are docile and not known to harm anyone.  Chuul move at Chuul speed and cannot be coaxed to go faster.

The Chuul are better suited for the climate of [[Ruje]] than any other pack animal.  The dampness of the jungle climate is found to not be suitable to other beasts of burden found throughout [[Asha]].  The Chuul enjoy the moist air, and are native to the jungle and wetland conditions.
Clan Earthhammer is a [[Dwarven|Dwarf]] family clan who are the founders of the city of [[Kulkar]].  The members of this family are known to be honorable, compassionate, and adventurous.  It is often that members of this clan become adventurers, seek out fortune or heroic deeds.  It is thus that the family founded the city of [[Kulkar]].  In recent years, [[Eiddoel Earthhammer III]] has been changing the perception of the family.  He is ruthless, cunning, and stubborn.  He craves power, wealth, and status - not just for himself but for all of the [[Dwarves|Dwarf]] of [[Kulkar]], making him a popular leader.

!Notable Members
[[Dargay Earthhammer]] was the crown prince of the clan, and joined [[The Grey Companions]] after an exile from his father.
[[Eiddoel Earthhammer III]] is the current [[Dorn]] of [[Kulkar]], and head of Clan Earthhammer
Note that classes of [[Asha]] differ slightly than that in the standard D&D Players Handbook.

| [img[images/classes/wizard-preview.jpg][documents/d&d5e/player-classes/class-wizard.pdf]] |
|  [[Wizard|documents/d&d5e/player-classes/class-wizard.pdf]] |
[>img[images/locations/ruje/closk.jpg]]
Closk is a remote village on [[The River Szitzus|The Szitzus]], within the jungle of [[Ruje]] known as [[The Sorrow]].  Few travelers venture as far as Closk, as the journey upriver grows treacherous and increasingly remote.  Known by many as the "Last Stop," Closk is where river traders turn back, unwilling to risk the dangers of the deeper mysteries and dangers of [[The Sorrow]]. The village itself is a humble but vibrant community built from the jungle’s abundant resources. Round huts line the riverbank, connected by curved pathways.  The sounds of nature dominate the air—birdsong, rustling leaves, and the ever-present hum of the jungle's countless insects.

The village is home to the [[Ngata'kay]], a proud and deeply spiritual group of tribal [[Humans|Human]] who have lived in harmony for generations with this portion of [[the jungle|The Sorrow]] that they have named [[The Bindwood]].  The [[Ngata'kay]] see themselves as stewards of [[The Bindwood]], charged with maintaining the delicate balance between man and nature.  They are known for being headhunters for those travelers of [[The Sorrow]] who do not treat it with the respect it demands.

!Culture and Way of Life
The [[Ngata'kay]] live off the land, relying on their knowledge of [[The Bindwood’s|The Bindwood]] [[flora and fauna|Bestiary]] to hunt, gather, and cultivate sustenance. They revere the jungle as a living, sentient entity, which they call [[The Bind|The Bindwood]].  Every [[Ngata'kay]] child learns the sacred traditions of their people, including songs, dances, and rituals to honor [[The Bind|The Bindwood]] and ensure its favor.

The tribe views outsiders with a mix of caution and curiosity.  They value their privacy and expect visitors to respect their ways.  Traders from downriver occasionally bring exotic goods to Closk, but transactions are conducted under the watchful eyes of the elders to ensure [[The Bind’s|The Bindwood]] sanctity is upheld.

!Notable Locations
* [[The Bindwood]] -  The dense jungle surrounding Closk, known locally as [[The Bindwood]], is both a source of life and a place of deep mystery.  [[The Bindwood]] is revered by the [[Ngata'kay]] as a living spirit that protects them but also tests their strength and resolve.  Its twisting paths are patrolled by [[Ngata'kay]] hunters, who ensure the jungle remains undisturbed by careless outsiders.
* [[The River Shrine]] - At the edge of [[The Szitzus]] lies a small shrine dedicated to [[The Bindwood]] and its guardian spirits.  Offerings of food, flowers, and carved wooden trinkets are left here daily by the villagers to ensure safe passage along the river and continued harmony with the jungle.
* [[Vreshka's Cradle]] - A sacred grove deep within [[The Bindwood]], [[Vreshka's Cradle]] is where the [[Ngata'kay]] believe the spirit of the jungle is strongest. It is marked by glowing trees and strange bioluminescent plants.  Outsiders are strictly forbidden from entering the grove without permission.
* [[The Cliff Caves Of Closk]] - Hidden within [[The Veil Of Ano-Khet]], the cliff on the other side of the river are caves used by the [[Ngata'kay]] for rituals and ancestor worship. The caves are filled with carvings, paintings, and offerings to the spirits. Legends tell of deeper tunnels that lead to forgotten secrets of the jungle.

!Notable People
| [img[images/characters/ruje/closk/toko-lai-portrait.jpg]] <br>[[Toko'Lai]] |[[Toko'Lai]] is the stern and enigmatic witch doctor of the [[Ngata’kay]] tribe, a revered elder who serves as the spiritual guardian of Closk.  His painted skull face, bone-adorned robes, and commanding presence strike fear and respect into all who encounter him. Deeply tied to [[The Bindwood]], he believes in preserving its sacred balance and sees outsiders as potential threats to its harmony.  [[Toko’Lai]] is particularly bitter toward [[Velyndra]], his former apprentice, who abandoned her training to seek a life beyond the jungle. |
[>img[images/bestiary/cockatrice.jpg]]

The cockatrice is a grotesque lizard creature that resembles the head and feet of a bird, and the wings of a bat.  Their skin is reptilian in nature, with proto-feather protrusions.  It is famous for the venom found within its mouth.  Even the smallest scratch can spell doom, as once the venom makes contact with the bloodstream, the victim must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution save or be magically petrified.  On a failed save, they begin to turn to stone and are restrained, making another save.  On a successful save, the effect ends - on a failed save the victim is paralyzed for 24 hours.

Their diet consists of any small animals that can fit in its mouth, however they are fiercely territorial and aggressive.  They fly into the face of any threat, squawking and madly beating their wings as its head darts out to peck.
The Consul was the highest political office of [[The Old Republic]].  Two consuls were elected each year, serving together and possessing veto power over the others actions.  This lessened the ability for one factions to abuse the kingly powers this role bestowed upon them.  Election was performed by [[The Old Republic Senate]], who therefore would customarily elect a Consul from the ruling nobility.

The duties of the Counsul were to preside over [[The Old Republic Senate]], and see that the laws and decrees were carried out.  All other governmental roles were subordinate to the Consuls.  They also acted on behalf of the regions of [[Kellos]] in matters of state, such as negotiations with other nations such as [[Dwarf]] or [[Elf]].

In order to grant the Consul with greater authority at executing law, they had the power to summon, detain and arrest.  In times of great emergency, they had the authority to act on their own authority and responsibility.
{{floatTableRight{
| [>img[images/file-icons/d&d5e-char-sheet-icon.png][documents/d&d5e/house-rules/houserule-corruption.pdf]] |
| [[House Rule|documents/d&d5e/house-rules/houserule-corruption.pdf]] |
}}}
[>img[images/magic/corruption.jpg]]
Corruption is a pervasive and insidious force that manifests in those who have tampered with [[aberant|Aberation]] and forbidden things.  Sustained contact with [[eldritch beings|The Elder Gods]] and locations, use of [[Blood Magic]], or other [[aberrant|Aberration]] actions cause a mortal [[Soul]] to take on corruption.  Corruption is like a virus, infecting the [[Soul]].  In small doses, this begins as madness and depravity; impulsiveness, hallucinations, paranoia or recklessness.  However, untreated corruption grows like a tumor mutating the physical form of a creature.

!Symptoms and Effects
Corruption manifests in many ways across one's Mind, Body, and [[Soul]].  Severity varies based upon the depth of exposure.  This includes distortion of the flesh, madness, paranoia, irrational obsessions, and ultimately loss of identity.  Corruption advances in stages, growing worse the longer one is exposed.  Early signs may be subtle - but over time, the affliction consumes the host.  The most severe cases become something wholly alien, reshaped into [[aberant|Aberation]] beings driven by primal hunger.

!Physical corruption of the land
When a physical location is corrupted, it is overcome with a viscous film, a lliving material known to scholars as [[Uridium]].  This substance is psionically-sensitive and may be influenced and controlled by [[Psionic|Psionics]] entities.
[>img[images/bestiary/crawling-creeper.jpg]]
Crawling Creeper is a creature native to [[Avernus]] within [[Baator]], living amongst the [[Vile Fungus]] common amongst fungal forest known as [[The Mold Thicket]].  Looking like a vine, it is actually a predatory creature that feeds on flesh and blood.  Whatever they can't digest they expel from their bodies, often littering the area with bone.

[>img[images/characters/kellos/the-elven-lands/the-high-forest/csaraasha.jpg]]
CsaraAsha (c. 792 [[IO]] to 206 [[AAP]]) ("To Yearn For Home" in [[Elvish]]) was a [[Forana'loloKashira]] [[Elf]] who lived in the [[Haven|Havens]] of [[Numeneithela]].  She was the mother of [[ElethaNori]] and the wife of the powerful [[Shaman]] of [[The Stag Clan]] [[NeneHwesta]].

!The Art Of Tea
CsaraAsha held great importance to a tea set that had been handed down from generations in her family.  It originated from [[The Sylvan Empire]] when [[Elvish|Elf]] civilization was at its peak.  The culture of tea was ingrained within CsaraAsha's family, and she was a master at  [[Lysathira]], the art of tea.  Together with her good friend [[Cala]], they would continuously meet to keep the dying art alive.

!The Fields Of Kalara
In 203 [[AAP]], CsaraAsha felt the calling of [[The Fields Of Kalara]].  As her husband [[NeneHwesta]] was the tribe [[Shaman]], he did not feel the calling with her; so she bore this burden silently, wishing to spend a few more years with her love.  Her close friend, [[Cala]] warned that it was dangerous to hold on to mortal ties, and it was for the best to let go and return to [[The Mother|Valouria]].
As CsaraAsha came to peace with the idea of leaving, she was startled to learn she was pregnant with her first child, [[ElethaNori]].  Childbirth had become increasingly rare among the [[Elves|Elf]], and this was a blessing from [[The Mother|Valouria]] although at an inopportune time.  CsaraAsha gathered her strength to prolong her stay, enduring much pain and anguish as she had already waited longer than necessary.  She was fearful that she would not be able to hold out long enough for the birth to occur, a fear that came true.  As her spirit left for [[The Fields Of Kalara]], her husband [[NeneHwesta]] used powerful [[Blood Magic]] in order to save the premature baby. 
[>img[images/bestiary/famous/culdranth.jpg]]

Culdranth was an ancient [[Dragon]] that had a lair in what is currently known as [[The Dales]] on the continent of [[Kellos]].  He was subdued by [[Armondax]], and is the [[Dragon]] referenced in the tome [[Treatise On Dragonkin]].

|>|!Currency|
|>|[[Cedula]] · [[Silver Red Queen|Red Queens]] · [[Copper Bandorian Thumb|BandorianThumb]] · [[Gold Kombarian Eye|KombarianEye]] · [[Black Pearl]] · [[Escudo]]|
!Introduction
[[Asha]] is abundant with different forms of currency and trade.  The [[wild nomadic tribesman of the northwestern territory|Kell]] use decorative strips of leather that they refer to as [[Cedula]]'s.  This simple form of currency is worthless outside of the [[nomadic people|Kell]] and is not recognized as a true currency of [[Asha]].  The [[Orcs]] are rumored to trade with teeth (taken from their fallen enemies).  Stranger still are the secluded island people of the western coast, who trade with small polished shells.  However, in the civilized lands only four major forms of currency are acknowledged: [[Bandorian “thumbs”|BandorianThumb]], [[Deepwater]] [[“Red Queens”|Red Queens]], [[Dwarven|Dwarf]] [[“Kombarian Eyes”|KombarianEye]], and Ancient [[Elven|Elf]] [[“Black Pearls”|Black Pearl]].

!Exchange Rates
1 Pearl		=	10 Eyes	=	100 Queens	=	1,000 Thumbs
While colloquially the term "Curse" is used to apply to any hostile magic that has a harmful effect, from a technical point of view a true Curse is a dark charm that is derived from [[Blood Magic]].  True Curses are heinous and dark, meant to cause immense suffering; or even death.  It is possible for a practitioner to Curse an object, a person, or a place.  While minor Curses can be fleeting and temporary, more potent Curses are permanent and can affect large areas of land or a family line as it is passed down through heredity.

!Breaking A Curse
There are multiple means by which a curse can be broken or removed.  Most curses can be broken by killing the practitioner who uttered the Curse.  Other methods include Divine magic of an equal level of power to the Curse itself.  The individual who invoked the Curse may willingly remove it at any time, however may not be inclined to do so without proper payment.  Lastly, a strong Curse may have a trigger condition that causes the Curse to break upon its action; eg a spurned [[Warlock]] curses a princess to appear ugly to all that she loved, until she showed respect and love to all. 
[>img[images/characters/kellos/cyril-viridian.jpg]]
{{quote{
//"We stand on the precipice of annihilation.  [[The Destruction Of Uskard]] was no accident, nor an isolated event - but the first stoke of a blade poised to cut us all down.  I have seen the signs, felt the scars it has left upon the children of [[Kellos]].  This is not a storm we can wait out.  It is a fire that will consume us all if we do not act."//
''-[[Consul]] Cyril Viridian, addressing [[The Amoni Assembly]]''
}}}

| ''See:'' [[The Viridian Empire]] · [[The Viridian Dynasty]] · [[The Destruction Of Uskard]] |

Cyril Viridian, (c. 61 [[IO]] - c. 11 [[AAP]]), was a Leader, Statesman, [[Praetor]] and [[Consul]] of [[The Amoni Republic]].  [[Kellish|Kell]] blood flowed strong in his veins, being descended from the kings of [[The First Men]] to inhabit [[Kellos]] and a proud member of [[The Valyriad]].  He was born in the waning century of [[The High Republic]], and was responsible for seceding [[Kellos]] from [[The Amoni Republic]] and establishing himself as [[Emperor]] of a new nation named [[The Viridian Empire]] in his honor.  Once in power, he made swift social and governmental reforms.  It was [[his dynasty|The Viridian Dynasty]] who disbanded [[The Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]], promoted [[The Divine Order]], changed the [[Calendar]], and re-established [[hereditary rule|Houses Of The Viridian Empire]].  Cyril is known most notably for his fight against [[Magic]], known as the [[Azutan Nagyos]], or "War of the Mages" in [[The Old Tongue]].

!A Fractured Kellos
In the last, desperate years of [[The High Republic]], the regions of [[Kellos]] groaned under the weight of their own divisions. [[The Dales]] were held by proud [[Mage-Lords]] who named their region [[The Zynovum Arcanum]], and draped themselves in both liberty and defiance.  Their creed was simple: that every lord, farmer, and mage alike should be left to their own devices, free from interference or higher authority. In the southeast, where modern-day [[Keep|The Keep]] and [[Coast|The Coast]] now stand, the region came to call itself [[The Valyriad]], a land defined by devout piety to the burgeoning [[Divine Order|The Divine Order]] and the belief that faith should guide both life and law.  [[The Northlands]] seethed with [[Kellish tribes|Kell]] who called themselves "The Free Peoples".  They remained untamed and unbowed, warring with the other regions of [[Kellos]] who they saw an invaders.  [[The Stone Lands]] endured, serving as the heart of [[Republic|The Amoni Republic]] ideals.  [[The Green Sea]] and parts of the modern day [[Keep|The Keep]] was largely [[Elvish|Elf]] owned or wild, and played little part in [[Human]] affairs at the time.  [[The Waste]] was not a waste or desert at all, but a lush and untapped wilderness being slowly consumed by an insectoid race known as the [[Thri-Keen]] who showed hostility to all who came near.

The [[Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]] at this time was discordant and unyielding. [[The Zynovum Arcanum]] and [[The Valyriad]] participated out of tradition.  However this melange of divergent philosophies mostly clashed until the chamber itself became a battlefield of words. Debate soured into venom, governance into paralysis, and unity into ruin. Where [[Kellos]] had once been the crown jewel of [[The Republic|The High Republic]], it now stumbled blind and broken toward collapse. It was in this crumbling world, amidst the ashes of consensus, that Cyril Viridian, rose to prominence and set his hand upon destiny.  He was born a member of the devout [[Valyriad|The Valyriad]], and grew disillusioned by the lack of speed and effectiveness in [[The Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]].

!Wars Against The Thri-Keen
Cyril first made his name not as a statesman, but as a soldier in the endless wars against the [[Thri-Keen]]. Hardened by blood-soaked skirmishes, he rose through grit and discipline to captain a small squad charged with holding the line against the hive-armies of [[The Waste]]. These insectoid swarms advanced like locusts, consuming entire ecosystems, stripping forests and fields until only barren earth remained. Time and again his company was thrown into desperate rearguards that did little more than contain the threat, yet Cyril endured, gaining a reputation for steadiness where others broke. The devastation left in the wake of the [[Thri-Keen]] seared itself into him, shaping both the soldier and the leader he would become.

!Role In The Demon Plague
In 24 [[IO]], an event known as [[The Demon Plague]] erupted and ravaged [[Kellos]], sowing terror, mutation, and madness in the form of [[Corruption]] among the populace. Twisted bodies and shattered minds spread like wildfire, and many whisper that moral decay itself had invited this scourge. It began near [[The Stone Lands]], and spread faster than it could be quelled. [[The Republic|The Amoni Republic]] faltered under the strain, with institutions crumbling and violence and fear spreading among the populace. Cyril, a veteran of the [[Thri-Keen]] wars and rising statesman of [[The Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]], was elected [[Praetor]]. He used his authority to unite fractured legions and local militias into a disciplined military force.  He established fortified encampments  in the afflicted regions, providing safe havens for refugees and rallying points for those resisting the [[plague's|The Demon Plague]] effects.

At the heart of this chaos was [[Morthas Dagon]], a [[Mage-Lord]] from [[The Zynovum Arcanum]] located in what is the modern day [[Dales|The Dales]].  He sought to orchestrate a new [[Desecration]] of [[Man|Human]].  The source uncovered, Cyril united with [[Elves|Elf]] of [[The Emerald Order]], an alliance that [[his dynasty|The Viridian Dynasty]] held long after his death.  Cyril's forces struck at [[Morthas's|Morthas Dagon]] [[cult|The Holy Scourge]] and their corrupted enclaves and captured [[Morthas|Morthas Dagon]] alive.  He was paraded through many cities in triumph, and seen for what he was: a [[Mage-Lord]] from [[The Zynovum Arcanum]].  Blame fell squarely on the [[Mage-Lords|Mage-Lord]], whose cries for liberty were seen as masks for their lust for power and twisted ideals.  This only served to make voices of [[The Amoni Assembly]] entrench deeper into their polarization.

!Election Of Consul
Cyril’s election to the office of [[Consul]] in 20 [[IO]] was the culmination of his career as both war hero and statesman. To the soldiers he was a savior, to the people a man of integrity, and to some on [[The Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]], a leader whose vision could restore unity to the faltering [[Republic|The High Republic]]. He entered office with high ideals, determined to heal the fractures of [[Kellos]] and rekindle the spirit of cooperation among splintered factions. Yet what he found in [[The Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]] was not resolve, but endless bureaucracy and obstruction. Each effort to advance reform was smothered by factional bickering, and the machinery of government ground against him like stone. Frustrated but not broken, Cyril pressed on, his frustration sharpening his conviction that only bold action, not hollow debate, could rescue [[Kellos]] from ruin.

!The Destruction Of The Thri-Keen
Cyril, frustrated with the bureaucracy of [[The Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]], put his mind and the resources at his disposal to end once and for all the endless skirmishes against the [[Thri-Keen]] of [[The Waste]].  These creatures, more plague than foe, had for centuries killed citizens and encroached on territory, leaving behind hollowed husks of land and dragging all spoils back to their [[Sietches|Sietch]].  Entire generations of [[Republic Forces|The Amoni Republic]] had been spent merely containing them, but Cyril believed only decisive annihilation would break their dominion.  Needing to gain the support of [[The Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]], he brought forth a proclamation of war for their consent.  [[The Amoni Assembly]] did not agree with much of anything, but became united behind Cyril's ask; not due to their belief in the mission, but instead because Cyril would be less dangerous to them if occupied.  To his surprise, they elected him [[Praetor]].  While unconventional to nominate a sitting [[Consul]] as [[Praetor]], many pointed out that there was precedent, and that Cyril was uniquely qualified.

With iron resolve, Cyril assembled the armies of [[Kellos]].  He waged ruthless campaigns to break the [[Thri-Keen]] through encirclement and fire, driving their surviving swarms back into [[The Waste]].  His victory at [[The Battle Of Red Sand]] in 13 [[IO]] was legend.  There he annihilated the [[Thri-Keen's|Thri-Keen]] largest hive-cluster, and slew their queen.  What had been a nightmare without end was at last silenced, ending generations of fear and marking him as savior of [[Kellos]].

!Secession And The Founding Of The Viridian Empire
In 9 [[IO]], Cyril's retirement after his term as [[Consul]] was disturbed when destiny itself arrived at his doorstep.  Ships from [[Uskard]], carrying the young [[Vesna Zeuxis]] and the displaced [[Uskardeen]] who fled [[The Destruction Of Uskard]] landed in his private homestead in [[The Keep]] near [[The Cauldron Sea]].  Recently [[a father|Thalos Viridian]], Cyril found himself moved by the young girl's fire.  [[Vesna|Vesna Zeuxis]] spoke of visions foretelling doom, a reckoning born of unchecked [[Magic]].  Unlike her father, Cyril Viridian listened and chose to bear her warnings before [[The Amoni Assembly]] to warn them of the impending carnage. Along the march to the capital, [[Vesna|Vesna Zeuxis]] confessed  that she had a vision where his [[Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]] was rotting from within, and would ignore them.  While dismayed, Cyril knew this to be true.  He could see the decay carved into the bones of [[Kellos]].  [[The Holy Scourge]] was again on the rise, sewing [[Corruption]] as it did decades earlier in his youth. 

The son of [[Morthas|Morthas Dagon]], [[Teldinath Dagon]] was an outspoken champion of [[The Zynovum Arcanum]] within [[The Amoni Assembly]].  When their pleas were dismissed and audience rebuffed, Cyril was outraged, certain it was [[Teldinath's|Teldinath Dagon]] scheming hand at work.  Ignoring the words of [[The Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]], Cyril took matters into his own hands. He traveled with [[Vesna|Vesna Zeuxis]] and her retinue, he and his family followed her on her vision to a promised land. [[Vesna|Vesna Zeuxis]] traveled to [[The Waste]] where her people occupied the empty [[Sietches|Sietch]] of the [[Thri-Keen]] and later carved the city of [[Amnar]].

[[Teldinath Dagon]] schemed to elect a fellow [[Mage-Lord]] as [[Praetor]].  He rallied [[Mage-Lord]] [[Fazar]], a hardened veteran of many campaigns within [[The Orcish Lands]] across [[The Cauldron Sea]], and his elite army of [[Zynovum Arcanum|The Zynovum Arcanum]] [[Sorcerers|Sorcery]] known as the [[Mage Guard]].  With the help from [[The Emerald Order]], Cyril held [[Fazar's|Fazar]] forces at bay.  But [[Teldinath|Teldinath Dagon]], like [[his father|Morthas Dagon]] before him, bent his knee to [[Zezebazum]].  When [[Taldinath|Teldinath Dagon]] failed to satisfy his patron's hunger, he was consumed and remade; his flesh twisted into a [[Deathlock]], a living conduit of despair whose [[Corruption]] spread like wildfire.  When Cyril discovered this, he called for the [[Azutan Nagyos]], the War Of The Mages, to purge [[Kellos]] of unchecked [[Magic]] that had birthed such abominations.

At first, the [[Mage-Lords|Mage-Lord]] of [[The Zynovum Arcanum]] rallied in defiance.  However the truth soon could not be denied.  [[Fazar]], [[Mysara]], [[Armondax]], and [[Waywill]] witnessed the ruin of [[Teldinath|Teldinath Dagon]] and the resurgence of [[The Holy Scourge]].  They knew then that [[The Zynovum Arcanum]] was diseased from within.  Choosing honor, they cast aside pride and swore alliance to Cyril.  Together with Cyril's forces and [[The Emerald Order]] they hunted the [[Deathlock]] to ruin, breaking his [[cult|The Holy Scourge]] and stemming the tide of [[Corruption]]

In the aftermath, [[Fazar]] and the other three remaining [[Mage-Lords|Mage-Lord]] conceded that [[Magic]], without chain or guide would forever endanger [[mankind|Human]].  At Cyril's decree [[The Zynovum Arcanum]] was disbanded and absorbed into a new nation.  The surviving [[Mage-Lords|Mage-Lord]] withdrew to [[The Isles]], where in the city of [[Zylok]] they formed [[The Fellowship Of Grand Mages]], a watchful order bound to protect [[mankind|Human]].  It was a compromise born of necessity; [[Magic]] would endure, but never again beyond the sight of [[The Empire|The Viridian Empire]].

Cyril emerged from the war as a hero and savior once again.  He united [[The Valyriad]], the broken lands of the former [[Zynovum Arcanum|The Zynovum Arcanum]], and the heart of [[The Republic|The High Republic]]: [[The Stone Lands]], into a single state.  In an act known as [[The Viridian Reforms]], he disbanded the dead husk of [[The Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]] and formally broke ties with the crumbling [[Republic|The Amoni Republic]], which in weakness could only capitulate.  Cyril restored the ancient powers of the [[Regeant Imperitor]] as in the time of [[Tarmon Gellius]], and before his death established a [[genetic dynasty|The Viridian Dynasty]] to become the [[Emperor]] of [[The Viridian Empire]].
Cyrilia is a celebration of [[Kellos]] that is observed on the 20th of [[Eleasis]] on [[The Viridian Calendar]].  The citizens of [[Kellos]] celebrate the founding of [[The Viridian Empire]], and the [[Emperor]].  The day is named after [[Cyril Viridian]], the first [[Emperor]] of [[The Viridian Empire]].

Celebrations often include a great bonfire in the square of each neighborhood, around which each community dances and gives gifts.
[>img[images/characters/kellos/the-coast/port-seamark/cyrus-bryne.jpg]]

Cyrus Bryne is the official head of [[House Bryne]], [[Shield]] of [[Port Seamark]], and [[Marshall]] of [[The Coast]].  He is stern, ambitious, and politically astute.  Cyrus's goal is to see his [[house|House Bryne]] stronger and more powerful than he found it.

Cyrus has a familial relationship with the [[Emperor]] [[Jacob Jedaleon III]], in that Cyrus's aunt [[Freya Bryne]] was the [[Emeror's|Emperor]] mother.  At a young age, Cyrus was appalled that his cousin was treated special, as the only heir to the throne.  This grew to a silent rage due to an incident in which Cyrus was force to concede a contest of arms to his older cousin, as it would be unseemly to best the [[Prince]] [[Jacob Jedaleon III]].

Cyrus's mother [[Estrella Bryne]] was tough on Cyrus as a child.  She expected the best out of Cyrus, and was not against beating the child when her high standards were not met exactly.  Her punishments included kicking an 8 year old Cyrus out of the castle for days for defying her wishes, ruthlessly killing his pet falcon as a lesson for training it to be docile rather than a hunter, and commanding a teenage Cyrus to behead a criminal himself to understand his true duty and obligation as a [[Lord]].

Cyrus's father was a kind man who was simply the face of [[House Bryne]].  Everyone knew [[Estrella Bryne]] ruled the household.  His father died when Cyrus was 19, and his mother was quick to name him the head of [[House Bryne]].  Say what you must of [[Estrella Bryne]], but for her faults all she wanted was to see her son rule - and rule strongly.
[>img[images/bestiary/ruje/monstrous/dachiata.jpg]]
The Dachiata is a nightmarish fusion of [[Bat]], [[Serpent]], and [[Cephalopod]], with an elongated body draped in leathery wings that stretch wide like a deathly shroud. Its head is crowned with retractable tentacle-like appendages, used both for sensory perception and for capturing prey. When extended, these appendages writhe and lash unpredictably, giving the Dachiata a fearsome and alien appearance.  It is found deep within [[The Jungles|The Sorrow]] of [[Ruje]].

Its clawed forelimbs, though small, are immensely strong, allowing it to grasp and anchor itself to cliff faces or high branches while waiting for unsuspecting prey to pass beneath. The lower body is long and flexible, capable of curling around prey in mid-air to constrict and immobilize before the kill.

Perhaps the most unnerving aspect of the Dachiata is its underbelly—lined with an array of membranous vents that can expand or contract to manipulate airflow. These vents give it an eerie ability to control its descent, allowing it to glide silently before striking with lethal precision.  There is usually no trace of it before it attacks other than a shadow upon the canopy of [[The Jungle|The Sorrow]].

!Hunting & Combat Tactics
The Dachiata is a consummate ambush predator. It stays aloft, gliding for days, descending in absolute silence, using its flexible abdomen to adjust its approach.  Upon reaching its target, it lashes out with its tentacle-like tendrils, wrapping them around its victim’s limbs to restrict movement. The tendrils secrete a mild paralyzing toxin, making escape almost impossible. As the prey struggles, the Dachiata’s razor-sharp fangs deliver the killing blow.

If forced into direct combat, the Dachiata uses its incredible agility to evade attacks, banking and twisting through the air. Its underbelly vents can be manipulated to generate sudden bursts of movement, making it exceptionally difficult to predict.
[>img[images/characters/kellos/the-stone-lands/brand/dargay.jpg]]

Dargay (893 [[AAP]] - 1021 [[AAP]]) was a [[Dwarf]] warrior of [[Clan Earthhammer]], crown prince of [[Kulkar]], adventurer, and member of [[The Grey Companions]].  While often brooding and grumpy, Dargay had a soft spot for his close friends, as well as children.  He preferred action to diplomacy, which caused him trouble more often than not.

!Life In Kulkar
Dargay Earthhammer was a crown prince of [[Kulkar]], the eldest son of [[Dorn]] [[Eiddoel Earthhammer II]].  He excelled at martial skills, becoming the head of [[Kulkar's|Kulkar]] military in 928 [[AAP]].  When his father began to show signs of struggling with dementia, Dargay searched for and found [[The Lost Hall Of The Mad Dorn]] with the hopes of uncovering a cure (to no avail).  When he challenged his father to step down from the throne, Dargay was exiled in 932 [[AAP]].  He didn't speak to his father all of the years leading up to his father's death in 943 [[AAP]]; where Dargay's younger brother [[Eiddoel Earthhammer III]] assumed the throne.

!Exile
The life of wandering adventure suited Dargay.  He served as a sailor on a trading vessel that travelled to the reaches of [[Amon]] and back.  Rumors abounded that he defeated [[The Leviathan Of The Fey Waters]] with brilliant naval tactics and cunning.  After over 70 years in exile, Dargay aimed to return to speak to his brother and mend past wounds.  Along the way he stopped in the city of [[Brand]], where he was swept up in the chaos that was [[The Red Pox]].  By reflex, he found himself helping control the panicked citizens and bring order back to the streets.  For his heroism, self-sacrifice, and service he was named to [[The Grey Companions]] in his 112th year by [[Liam Mercer]] in 1005 [[AAP]]
[>img[images/bestiary/the-shadowfell/darkweaver.jpg]]
Dark Weavers are a species of colossal arachnid native to [[The Shadowfell]].  They are terrifying predators whose central torso can grow to the size of a cow, with legs that span 5 feet.  They are known for their cunning intelligence and lethal efficiency, making them one of the most efficient killers lurking within the shadows of [[The Shadowfell]].

Their bodies are covered in a thick, chitinous exoskeleton that ranges in color from deep obsidian black to shadowy grey, allowing them to blend seamlessly into their dark surroundings.  Their legs end in sharp, hooked claws that enable them to climb with ease.  Each leg is covered in bristling, coarse hairs that can sense the faintest vibrations in the air or ground, alerting them to the presence of potential prey.

Dark Weavers are known to weave their webs in strategic locations, often creating elaborate traps that funnel prey into a narrow corridor or pit.  They are patient hunters, waiting silently in the shadows for days or even weeks until the perfect moment to strike.  The webs themselves are also used as a means of communications between Dark Weavers, allowing them to send subtle vibrations to one another over long distances.  However, Dark Weavers are solitary by nature, each claiming a vast territory within [[The Shadowfell]].  They are extremely territorial and will fiercely defend their lairs from intruders, including other Dark Weavers.  Their hunting tactics are methodical and ruthless; they prefer to weaken their prey by ambush, relying on the element of surprise and their lethal webs to do most of the work.
[>img[images/races/darkling.jpg]]

Be they the children of migrant [[Humans|Human]] seeking refuge in [[Dwarven|Dwarf]] kingdoms, or of [[Dwarven|Dwarf]] merchants who struck rich in the wide open world, the half-dwarves (more commonly known as Darklings) share a mix of traits from both of their parent races. Some say that [[Dwarven|Dwarf]] blood tempers [[Human]] impatience, while others say that [[Human]] heritage allows them to be more flexible than the stone.  The existence of [[Half-Dwarfs|Half-Dwarf]] is as old as their ancestors, though less common. 

!Not Welcome In Either World
There is no taboo against [[Humans|Human]] and [[Dwarves|Dwarf]] breeding, but it is a very rare occurrence; this makes the Darklings misfits and outcasts.  Not feeling a sense of belonging in either community, they are known as [[Sewer Dwarves]] by the [[Human]] civilization, and [[Aalvtaurag]] of "half beards" by the [[Kombar''ran|Dwarf]].

!Their father's nose, their mother's eyes
To [[Humans|Human]], Darklings look like tall [[Dwarves|Dwarf]], and to [[Dwarves|Dwarf]], they look like short [[Humans|Human]]. They typically sit in the middle range of heights between their parents, although they're a little bulkier than the average [[Human]].

!Children Of The Underworld
It is common for Darklings to find work in the criminal underworld, as the race is downtrodden and are alienated by those [[Humans|Human]] and [[Dwarves|Dwarf]] who are more traditionalist in their thinking.  Because of the abject racism they experience, Darklings always expect trouble and know it is safest to protect oneself with armor and weapon when traveling in [[Human]] or [[Dwarvish|Dwarf]] settlements.  Certain situations must be backed up by force, and you will never know when someone will try and take advantage of you.  They have a distinct feeling that everyone else is plotting and scheming in the same way they are.

!Darkling Cunning
Darklings have to be cunning to survive.  They know how to manipulate situations to their advantage, with a mix of [[Dwarven|Dwarf]] greed and [[Human]] adaptability.  Darklings are notoriously tight-fisted, and generally acknowledged to be just as reluctant as [[Dwarves|Dwarf]] to part with their money.  They are tough bargainers and shrewd merchants, and often buy no more than what they need.  The only way to get a Darkling to part with a penny is to offer him a wager, most Darklings enjoy games of chance.  Anyone that is able to out-wit or get the best of a Darkling in a deal will earn his respect and that of other Darklings as well.  Often a Darkling will tell a good story of cunning, even if he himself was out witted.  

!The Gang Is Their Home
Darklings don’t labor or build strongholds of their own.  They consider themselves just a bit more clever than everyone else, allowing other races to toil maintaining civilization while the Darklings reap all of the rewards.  Darklings often form into [[gangs|Darkling Gang]] for safety.  A gang leader is called the [[Cloak|Darkling Cloak]].  Males do not necessarily dominate the [[Darkling Gang]], whoever is the most powerful and most cunning usually leads.  The [[Darkling Cloak]] is ultimately responsible for the actions of his gang, and they operate under his protection.  Gang members always give their [[Darkling Cloak]] a cut of whatever they steal or make.   If anyone ever fails the [[Darkling Cloak]], they are exiled from the [[Darkling Gang]].  The only way to return is to kill a rival of the [[Darkling Cloak]].  Darklings who betray the [[Darkling Cloak]] or rat on a gang member are hunted until they are killed.  The [[Darkling Cloak]] of a Darkling gang is a highly respected individual.  Their orders are carried out indiscriminately, and failure often has due consequences.  Some [[Cloak’s|Darkling Cloak]] are malicious and controlling, treating their [[Darkling Gang]] members as lackey’s or goons.  However most [[Cloaks|Darkling Cloak]] deal with their members as if they were family.  The leadership style of a [[Darkling Cloak]] varies from gang to gang, but all [[Cloak’s|Darkling Cloak]] realize that their power may be challenged at any moment.

All [[gangs|Darkling Gang]] have a distinct name and symbol, which they carry with pride.  Quite often, the most powerful of the [[Darkling Gangs|Darkling Gang]] within a [[Human]] city will operate above ground.  Those that do, often own legitimate businesses to use as a front for their underground operations.  These bold and crafty gangs are well respected among the Darkling community.

|statblock5e|k
|font-size: 23px;color:#7A200D;font-variant:small-caps;''Darkling''|
|//The Darkling are kin to both [[Human]] and [[Dwarf]], but don't feel welcome in either community.//|
|<hr/>|
|''Ability Score Increase:'' Constitution +2, and one ability score of your choice +1.|
|''Age:'' Darklings mature at the same rate as [[Humans|Human]].|
|''Size:'' Darklings are bulkier than most [[Humans|Human]], but taller than most [[Dwarves|Dwarf]], standing between 4-and-a-half and 5-and-a-half feet tall, and can weigh anywhere from 150 to 250 pounds. Their size is Medium.|
|''Speed:'' Base walking speed is 25 feet.  Speed is not reduced in heavy armor.|
|<hr/>|
|''Infravision:'' Darklings have [[Infravision]] granting the ability to see heat signatures in low-light conditions up to 60 feet - and in complete darkness as if it was dim-light.|
|''Dwarven Resilience:'' A [[Dwarven|Dwarf]] bloodline provides an have advantage on saving throws against poison, as well as resistance to poison damage.|
|''Cunning:'' They have proficiency with two skills of their choice.|
|''Languages:'' Can speak, read, and write [[The Common Tongue]] and [[Dwarvish]].|
{{floatTableRight{
| [>img[images/file-icons/d&d5e-char-sheet-icon.png][documents/d&d5e/house-rules/houserule-senses.pdf]] |
| [[House Rule|documents/d&d5e/house-rules/houserule-senses.pdf]] |
}}}

A creature with darkvision can see in dim light as if it were bright light and in darkness as if it were dim light; however the creature cannot discern color in that darkness, only shades of grey.
Dathairä (translated as "children of death" in the [[Elvish]] tongue) are supernatural beings that feed on the evil of sentient beings.  They are servants to their creator, [[Azarad-Ji]] - who use the Dathairä to secretly manipulate [[Asha]] to perpetuate chaos, senseless violence and bring about [[Desecration]].  Those skilled in the dark art of [[Blood Magic]] have the power to summon the Dathairä, and petition them for favors.  The Dathairä are known to grant their most loyal servants enormous power - for a price.  Dathairä are known as [[The Corruptors]], [[The Eaters Of Life]], [[The Demiurges]] - [[Uskardeen]] mythology call them the [[Mayombe]], or cannibal spirits.  They vary greatly in power, type and orientation.  They obediently follow [[The Infernal Hierarchy]], in which those Dathairä in positions of power rule over their lesser kin.

While Dathairä serve [[Azarad-Ji]], their master lies locked within a prison of divine making.  In the meantime, the Dathairä are content to manipulate the mortal world in their unrelenting master's absence from the relative safety of their home in [[Baator]].

!Life Beyond Death
Dathairä who perish can find themselves reborn within [[The Kiln Of The Profaned]], located in [[Baator]].  This painful and lengthy process requires a hefty amount of [[Souls|Soul]] to feed the rebirth.  The process is overseen by the [[Duke]] of [[Stygia]].  Failure to have the appropriate funds on hand at this time of need results in the Dathairä's destruction, or devolution to a minor form.

!Known Dathairä
| [img[images/darkones/drelmor-portrait.jpg][Drelmor]] <br>[[Drelmor]] |__[[Drelmor]]__ was the first child of [[Azarad-Ji]].  Strong, fierce and loyal.  He led the Dathairä in battle in [[The Second Age]], bringing ruin to [[The Planes Of Existence]] wherever his armies marched; butchering [[AstraKashira]] by the score, removing their prized wings before torturing and killing them.  Drelmor was eventually defeated by [[ImoMahtara]] with [[The Spire Of Planes]] - eradicating both of them from existence. |
| [img[images/darkones/zezebazum-portrait.jpg][Zezebazum]] <br>[[Zezebazum]] |__[[Zezebazum]]__ is one of the most ancient and powerful [[Dathairä]].  Responsible for the demise of [[The Sylvan Empire]], the [[Elves|Elf]] name him Quenaachawiere, or "the deceiver".  Driven to bring about [[Desecration]] he nearly ended [[The Fourth Age]] in a conflict known as [[The Demon Plague]].  Countless deaths and atrocities are on his hands, however his cunning and power to take on familiar shapes grants him the ability to beguile with a silver tongue. |
| [img[images/darkones/shargaas-portrait.jpg][Shargaas]] [[Shargaas]] |__[[Shargaas]]__ is the master of shadows and darkness.  She possesses large tentacle appendages sprouting from her head and back which can be used to grasp and fight.  She is weakened by sunlight, where she is completely blind - however she has perfect dark vision and can see even without the existence of light. |
| [img[images/darkones/yurtrus-portrait.jpg][Yurtrus]] [[Yurtrus]] |__[[Yurtrus]]__ is the [[Duke]] of [[Phlegethos]], [[The Circle Of Lust|Phlegethos]] in [[Baator]].  She is fascinated by the mortal life force, and the power contained within.  She has the power to influence and seduce the male mind, and is known as The Queen Of Whispers for the knowledge she can extract from her victims.  She is a practiced diviner; able to predict and understand both past or future - and has been known to be fond and amused of mortals that call for her service.  |
| [img[images/darkones/urdlen-portrait.jpg][Urdlen]] [[Urdlen]] |__[[Urdlen]]__ strikes fear into those who lay eyes on him.  While humanoid in shape, his face and body are made up of protrusions of dark bone.  He is always accompanied by two or more beasts known as [[Sulkers|Sulker]], which serve him loyally.  He generates fear, causing the blood to pump - blood which he greatly desires. |

!Lesser Known Dathairä
[[Vaecna]], [[Vergadain]], [[Berronar]], [[Faenya]], [[Erevan]] - Mischief / Change, [[Solonar]] - The Hunt, [[Celanil]], [[Flandil]], [[Arawn]], [[Mannannan]], [[Gargauth Souldrinker]], [[Belphagor]], [[Mahadi]], [[Brazelus]]

[>img[images/bestiary/ruje/death-scarab.jpg]]
The Death Scarab is a remarkable and infamous species of beetle native to the dense, humid jungles of [[Ruje]].  Roughly the size of a human thumb, these colorful, glistening beetles have unique biological properties that have traditionally made them useful in [[Blood Magic]] rituals.  They are natural scavengers, feeding on carrion in the wild.  They are hardy creatures, capable of surviving long periods without food as they enter a dormant state until needed.  Their feeding habits make them an essential part of the jungle's ecosystem, aiding in the decomposition process.

!The Sacrament
[[The Medica]] had once perfected a process known as [[The Sacrament]], which transformed a humble Death Scarab into an [[Envoy]] which when implanted into a [[Human]] host could unnaturally prolong life.  This processed ceased working in 1026 [[AAP]] when the [[Apotheon]] [[Samuanya]] cursed the process.
[>img[images/afflictions/possessions/deathlock.jpg]]
A Deathlock is the grim consequence of a [[Warlock]] breaking their sacred bond with their [[Patron]]. Forging a pact with a [[Patron]] is no trivial matter; it is a binding agreement with profound implications. While a [[Warlock]] may live out their mortal years after rejecting their [[Patron]], the true punishment begins upon their death. In death, the [[Patron]] [[possess|Afflictions]] the [[Warlock]], seizing complete control of the [[Warlock's|Warlock]] body and [[Soul]], transforming them into a Deathlock—a horrifying puppet of their former self, now enslaved to serve the [[Patron's|Patron]] will.

!The Fate of the Fallen
Upon death, the [[Soul]] of the [[Warlock]] is denied any passage to an afterlife, remaining forever bound to the [[Patron]]. The [[Patron]] erases all free will from the Deathlock’s mind, leaving the [[Warlock’s|Warlock]] consciousness trapped within, forced to witness their body commit atrocities without any ability to intervene. The [[Patron]] uses this opportunity to undo any good deeds, relationships, or accomplishments the [[Warlock]] achieved in life, making them destroy loved ones, allies, and everything they once held dear.  While the [[Patron]] despises disloyalty, they perversely wish for the [[Warlock]] to live the happiest and most successful life possible before their death, as the more profound the suffering they can impose.  This cruel punishment serves as a warning to other [[Warlocks|Warlock]] of the consequences of breaking their bond.

!Eternal Service
Once awakened, a Deathlock is consumed by an overpowering urge to serve its [[Patron]]. Any goals, ambitions, or desires it held in life are erased, replaced entirely by the [[Patron's|Patron]] directives. Though a Deathlock does not possess true free will, it retains some autonomy in devising tactics and executing its master's plans. This limited independence allows it to act as an effective and cunning agent of the [[Patron]], carrying out schemes with precision and intellect. &nbsp;It also adds to the pain of the punishment, ensuring the [[Warlock]] is just conscious enough to know what they are doing.

Once the [[Warlock's|Warlock]] legacy has been dismantled, a [[Patron]] uses a Deathlock as a tool for their most audacious and desperate schemes. These  servants are sent on monumental and often impossible missions, such as sowing chaos, dismantling faiths, or toppling entire kingdoms. Unlike the careful and subtle manipulations of a [[Warlock]], a Deathlock is a blunt instrument of destruction, a final gamble by the [[Patron]] to achieve their ends with little concern for success or failure. To the [[Patron]], deploying a Deathlock is less about ensuring victory and more about discarding a broken servant in a manner that might still serve some purpose. Other [[Warlocks|Warlock]] or covens may be called to assist when a Deathlock is unleashed, though they do so with great hesitation and dread. The appearance of a Deathlock is a dire omen, a harbinger of monumental upheaval and destruction, akin to witnessing an avatar of the [[Patron's|Patron]] wrath made manifest. For all who behold it, the presence of a Deathlock signals that the [[Patron]] is interfering directly, with devastating consequences certain to follow.

!A Warning to All
The existence of Deathlocks is a chilling reminder of the weight and consequences of a [[Warlock's|Warlock]] pact. While the relationship between a [[Warlock]] and a [[Patron]] is often one of mutual benefit—a quid-pro-quo exchange of power for service—any failure to fulfill the agreed-upon terms invites the [[Patron's|Patron]] wrath. The creation of a Deathlock is not merely a punishment for the offending [[Warlock]] but a demonstration of the [[Patron's|Patron]] power to all others who might consider betrayal.
The creation of a Deathlock is a painstaking, time-consuming, and costly endeavor for the [[Patron]], yet they undertake it without hesitation.
