|''Tail.''  //Melee Weapon Attack:// +6 to hit, range 15 ft., one target.  //Hit:// 14 (2d10 +3) bludgeoning  damage.  If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is grappled (escape DC 12)|>|>|>|>|>|

[>img[images/characters/the-feywild/archfey/llvarana.jpg]]
Llvarana, known as "The Last Illumination" in [[Elvish]] and the Alderking, is the [[Archfey]] ruler of [[The Court Of Sun]] and the [[Fomorian]] [[Sovereign|Fey King]] of [[BaraDore]].  His domain, once resplendent, was shattered in the brutal [[War Of The Feywild|The War Of The Feywild]], waged against [[VanwaHeru]].  Llvarana was the last-awoken of the [[Archfey]] and the only one among them who embraces change, which sets him apart from his kin who remain static and unchanging.  The [[Fomorians|Fomorian]] and [[The Fell Folk]] under his rule were once [[Eldarin]] and [[Fey]] who became afflicted during the destruction of [[The Court Of Sun]] into twisted forms that cause them constant pain.  Llvarana, rather than shunning their deformities, embraces them, seeing their suffering as a manifestation of their true, inner selves.

Llvarana's philosophy revolves around revealing the inner truths and tearing away illusions, believing that accepting one's imperfections and embracing primal nature leads to true strength.  While other [[Courts Of The Feywild|Archfey]] focus on beauty, deception, and glamour, Llvarana believes they are deluded by their failure to acknowledge the power of their true, inner selves. As such, he sees himself as a necessary counterbalance to the chaos and stagnation in [[The Feywild]], accepting the mantle of villain for the greater good.

!The Court Of Sun
Where [[The Court Of Sun]] used to be exists simply nothing, as if it was simply excised and surgically removed from [[The Feywild]] with a jagged knife by [[VanwaHeru]].  The destruction of [[The Court Of Sun]] left only the floating island of [[BaraDore]], a place of perpetual black fog and shifting landscapes. It mirrors Llvarana’s unpredictable nature and his rule, which is characterized by ruthless power plays and cunning manipulation. The island's doors open to any [[plane of existence|The Planes Of Existence]], reflecting his deep knowledge of the rules of [[The Feywild]], which he exploits to his advantage. 

After the fall of [[VanwaHeru]], [[The Feywild]], a realm that thrives on balance, has gifted Llvarana a unique and formidable power. As the [[Archfey]] of [[The Court Of Sun]] and the only [[Archfey]] to accept change, Llvarana now holds the power of two courts. His connection to both the sun and stars makes him an unparalleled force within [[The Feywild]], one whose power dwarfs that of his rivals. The other [[Archfey]] are unaware of this hidden shift in power, attributing his newfound strength to his ruthless cunning and mastery of [[Feywild|The Feywild]] laws. Unbeknownst to them, the absence of [[VanwaHeru]] has elevated Llvarana to an almost invincible status, making him a dangerous and elusive villain, and one whom none dare challenge outright.

!The War Of The Feywild
Llvarana's personal story is one of tragedy and loss, whose tragic fate revolves around his lost love, [[Lady Alastai]], former [[Queen|Fey Queen]] of [[The Dawn Court]]. His love for her was revealed only shortly before [[the war with VanwaHeru|The War Of The Feywild]], ignited by a tattoo given to him by the foreseer [[Naurase]]. This tattoo showed him the [[Archfey]] he was [[Fated]] to love holding two twins with striking resemblance to the current rulers of [[The Dawn Court]], to his surprise. When [[the war|The War Of The Feywild]] erupted, Llvarana fought valiantly to protect [[Lady Alastai]], attempting to give his own life willingly to protect her, even though they had never spoken of [[their bond|Fated]].  This action caused Llvarana to be disfigured. While he did save her from ultimate destruction, she was split into two beings. 

However, following the [[cataclysmic war|The War Of The Feywild]], the [[Archfey]] chose to remove all memories of [[VanwaHeru]], [[Naurase]], and the events leading up to the conflict. Llvarana, too, was stripped of his memories, including the knowledge of his [[Fated]] love for [[Lady Alastai]]. Despite this, he is left with the tattoo of a woman he no longer recalls but deeply knows he loves. Haunted by the absence of his memories, Llvarana roams [[The Feywild]], seeking the lost love he cannot name, driven by the enduring pull of his [[Fated]] connection.  He is confused by the fact that his tattoo shows his love holding twins that have a striking resemblance to the current rulers of [[The Dawn Court]], his current enemy.

!The Wild Hunt
[[The Wild Hunt]] is the name given to the event that occurs every 500 years when [[The Echo Planes]] are in [[Conjunction|The Conjunction Of The Echo Planes]] and the veil between worlds is thin.  It is a barbaric display of fulfilling base and wanton desires, showcasing the true chaos of [[The Fell Folk]].  While it is often looked down upon by the other [[Archfey]], Llvarana encourages his [[Court|The Court Of Sun]] to revel in primal desires and chaos, showcasing their ruthlessness. During the hunt, they capture mortals and drain their memories and dreams, using them for their dark rituals. Llvarana's pursuit of power and his fixation on unraveling mysteries, particularly those concerning [[The Forgotten Prince|VanwaHeru]] and [[his lost love|Lady Alastai]], drive much of his ambition and curiosity within [[The Material Plane]]. He is both feared and respected, standing as one of the most enigmatic and powerful figures in [[The Feywild]], embodying both the light of revelation and the darkness of torment.
In [[the feudal system|Feudalism]] of [[The Viridian Empire]], the title of Lord (for male) or Lady (for females) is a title signifying their feudal ownership of land.  The title, authority, and lands are bestowed by lineage and through seniority - or bestowed by the [[Emperor]].

It is a Lord's responsibility to see to the affairs of the lands they own, and the people that live there.  They are expected to keep the peace, judge on local matters, and ensure the taxes due [[The Viridian Empire]] are collected in a timely manner.
[>img[images/characters/the-feywild/archfey/filvenedore.jpg]]
Lord Filvenedore ("The Exalted Black Frost" in [[Elvish]]) is the [[Archfey]] who is [[King|Fey King]] of [[The Winter Court]]. He is also known as The Pale Prince, The Frozen King, and The Lord Of The Winter Heart.  While he is not cruel, he does not carry mercy within his heart. He allies with the other [[Archfey]] only when facing the most dire threats, preferring to deal with his enemies quickly and viciously. He holds mortals and non-Fey in contempt, seeing them as fickle and untrustworthy. Lord Filvenedore does not delight in the merrymaking and adornment of flowers and beauty like his allies. He sees these things as unnecessary, instead focusing his attention on thwarting the [[Fomorians|Fomorian]] from gaining a stronger foothold in his domain, and bringing his wife back from her slumber.

Filvenedore is selfless and proud of his domain and the people of [[The Winter Court]].  He lives in [[Velivelo]] ("The White City" in [[Elvish]]), where he keeps a number of his frozen enemies as ice statues.

His favored servant is his general [[Akut]], a White [[Phoenix]] who serves Filvenedore faithfully.  [[Akut]] is honorable, noble, and valiant and sees those same qualities within his [[King|Fey King]].  They have undying trust within each other and their abilities, and both are loyal to one another.  [[Akut]] is himself a [[King|Fey King]], and commands all [[Phoenix]] of [[The Feywild]].  While solitary creatures, they would come to his call and fight in his honor.  [[Akut]] and Filenedore have mutual respect for each other and treat each other as equals.

Filvenedore's [[Queen|Fey Queen]] is [[Naurase]] ("The Exulted North Wind" in [[Elvish]]) who countered his harshness with beauty, grace, and calmness.  She slumbers gracefully in a bed of ice, suffering from an unknown illness that holds her in an endless sleep.  It is [[Naurase]] who even in her slumber paints the sky across [[The Echo Planes]] with breathtaking beauty in what is known as [[The Aurora Borealis]].  While the memory has been taken from all, [[Naurase]] is the daughter of [[VanwaHeru]] and aided in his dark plot for [[The Feywild]].  It was the [[Archfey]], including Filvenedore who chose to punish her with endless sleep in [[Sene'Rine'Rada]]; however he did not have the heart to banish her body.
[>img[images/characters/the-feywild/archfey/orane.jpg]]
Lord Orane ("The Exalted Hunter" in [[Elvish]]) is a strong, quiet and steadfast [[Archfey]].  He is the [[King|Fey King]] of [[The Spring Court]], and unmatched as a hunter and woodland warrior.  It was Lord Orane who crafted the city of [[Senaliesse]] as a symbol of his love for [[Lady Kalamantri]].  He often acts in tandem with her when [[The Court Of Stars]] is in session.

Lord Orane is kind and majestic, quiet and contemplative - however when provoked he is quick to act.  Many compare his demeanor to that of a lion.  He has gathered a tremendous amount of respect from his people and the other [[Archfey]], who value his council and wisdom.  He has the unwavering loyalty of [[Treants|Treant]], [[Dryads|Dryad]], and [[Nymphs|Nymph]] within his kingdom. 

!Fey Of The People
More than any other [[Archfey]], Lord Orane dedicates himself to his subjects, and is attuned to each and every individual within his care.  He is constantly traveling and patrolling his realm, seeing to it's meticulous safety and upkeep, and he enjoys making genuine connections with every branch and bough; he is very loved by the citizens of [[The Spring Court]].  It is difficult to enter his domain without his personal knowledge, and it is common for Lord Orane to personally greet new visitors upon first stepping foot within his realm.  He shows fondness towards mortals who stumble into [[The Feywild]], and is known to guide them or offer them sanctuary before helping them on their way.

!A Giver Of Gifts
Contrary to [[Fey]] custom, Lord Orane does not strictly hold himself to some of the ideals of the [[Fey]].  For example, he rarely expects gifts to be repaid in kind, and generously offers his time and resources as a token of love and appreciation.  He famously gifted the city of [[Senaliesse]] to [[Lady Kalamantri]], and is known to provide gifts of service to his subjects as he travels his land.

!Steward Of Goll
When a [[Fomorian]] attack penetrated into [[The Court Of Stars]], it was Lord Orane who met them in battle.  He showed them no mercy, defending the realms with no remorse.  He felt conflicted when a lone [[Fomorian]] child lay defenseless on the battlefield.  Lord Orane felt in that moment the same need to protect the unprotected as he did with his own subjects.  At the disdain from the other courts, Lord Orane took the child as his own to raise; wishing to prove that a heart of a [[Fomorian]] can also show love and compassion if they are properly raised.  This child, named [[Goll]], was cursed by [[Lord Filvenedore]] such that if [[Goll]] did not perform an act of true selfless love by his 18th year, his life was forfeit.

Lord Orane places much faith and trust in [[Goll]], more than most feel is wise.  His people are wary of [[Goll]], but reluctantly trust their lord's judgement; and would never think of going against his pleasure.  While Lord Orane is often otherwise occupied within his realm, he places the orchestration of [[The Spring Court]] in [[Goll's|Goll]] hands, with the assistance of his capable advisor, [[Greyhusk]], an ancient [[Treant]] who is a paragon of patience and structure.
{{floatTableRight{
| [>img[images/file-icons/d&d5e-char-sheet-icon.png][documents/d&d5e/house-rules/houserule-lorechant.pdf]] |
| [[House Rule|documents/d&d5e/house-rules/houserule-lorechant.pdf]] |
}}}
Lorechant is a chaotic and instinctual form of [[Magic]] practiced by [[The Small Folk]] and [[Goblinoid|Goblin]] creatures of [[The Feywild]]. Unlike the refined [[Sorcery]] of the [[Eldarin]] or the solemn rites of [[Treants|Treant]], Lorechant is improvised, impulsive, and deeply personal.  It is a kind of [[Magic]] that is felt, not learned. It draws from the primal energies of [[The Feywild]], shaped by emotion, each casting performed through improvisation of rhyme riddle and whim, rather than formal study or tradition.

To outsiders, Lorechant may seem crude or like laughable nonsense, but its strange potency is undeniable: equal parts luck, madness, and mischief. It is art more than science.  Casting is spontaneous, colorful, and often loud, with results that range from wondrous to disastrous. A clever phrase might open a door in a tree, or cause a stone to leap like a frog; or unpredictably explode into confetti or transport the Lorechanter into a wine barrel.  Lorechanters never use tomes or scrolls, as each incantation must be unique and personal.  Given the magic is fickle and unpredictable, even those who have mastered the knack are terrified of the potential danger of a misplaced phrase.

Despite its instability, Lorechant is governed by The 7 Laws Of Lorechant. These aren’t simple guidelines or traditions but immutable, irrefutable, and unbreakable rules woven into the very fabric of Lorechant itself. Even the most powerful [[Archfey]] cannot bend them. To ignore these laws is not to risk failure, it is to invite disaster, absurdity, or magical embarrassment of the highest order.

!The Seven Laws Of Lorechant
# ''The Law Of The Gift'' - Only [[The Small Folk]] of [[The Feywild]] posses the ability to Lorechant, and nobody knows why. It is strongest among the [[Korred]] and the [[Goblinoids|Goblin]], and it cannot be taught, only felt. Something ancient and unknown binds it to them alone.
# ''The Law Of The Rhyme'' - Lorechant is based on rhyming.  One must first pick a single word to describe the intended/desired effect, then create a chant phrase where each word in the phrase starts with a sequential letter in the chosen word. Both the root word and the phrase must describe the intended effect of the incantation (e.g. hole -> “Hope Opens Lovely Exit” to escape from a locked room). The complexity, creativity, relevance, and clarity of the rhyme directly affect the spell’s strength and duration.
# ''The Law Of Sentimentality'' - Lorechant ''//requires//'' a material component that rhymes with the names effect in Law #2 to function (eg a “bowl”).  This item is sacrificed and destroyed during casting.  The more powerful the sentimental value of this object, the more powerful the resulting effect.  The caster ''//MUST//'' own this item (and it cannot be a stolen item), but the sentimental value may be someone else’s (a sold or traded wedding ring, for example).
# ''The Law Of Limits'' - Lorechant is grounded in the physical world and cannot affect intangible concepts such as time or love. It also cannot directly cause harm or death to living creatures, or be used to summon or create sentient things, including spirits or constructs. Attempts to break these limits result in random harmless, nonsensical effects (e.g., a puff of smoke shaped like a frog, or harmless sparks). Lastly, most effects from Lorechant last for a few seconds or minutes, based upon the phrase complexity, rhyming nuance and sentimentality of the chant.
# ''The Law Of Complexity'' - The effectiveness of a Lorechant effect depends on the complexity of the rhyming and phrasing. Simple rhymes and phrases may create minor, fleeting effects, while more intricate and clever rhymes allow for more potent outcomes.
# ''The Law Of Gibberish'' - The lorechanter must fully understand and truly believe in the meaning of the words they are rhyming. Gibberish, or deliberate misuse or mispronunciation results in comical misfires, dud effects, or worse.
# ''The Law Of The Price'' - Lorechant always takes a toll. Whether it works or fizzles, each casting imposes exhaustion on the caster. [[The Feywild]] exacts a price for every twist in its rules.  For the right price, even some of the laws of Lorechant can be bent or broken.
[>img[images/characters/original-grey-companions/lucerius-poulcheria-aurellian.jpg]]
Lucerius Poulcheria Aurellian (1844 [[IO]] - 1750 [[IO]]),  Innocentius, The First Cantor, The Prophet Of The Cycle, The Golden Fang, The Light Of Brand was a [[Human]] [[Cleric]], scholar, gifted with [[Foretelling]], whose teachings reshaped [[theology|Religion]] of [[Kellos]] in [[The High Republic Era|The High Republic]] of [[The Amoni Republic]].  A founding member of [[The Grey Companions]], he had immense loyalty to [[Tarmon Gellius]].

!Early Life
Born in the holy city of [[Poulcheriople]], to a noble house, Lucerius was wracked with with uncontrollable visions at the age of 5.  He would envision the sky on fire, a city burning, and people dying.  He described it as "a song sung backward and forward through time".  Perplexed at what to do, his parents dedicated him as a ward to [[The Canticle]], to be raised in service to [[The Sovereigns|Elysian]].  Lucerius was trained in the seminaries of [[The Chant Of Light]], a rigid faith that worshiped the pantheon of [[The Elysians|Elysian]].  His bloodline was blessed to be descended from the prophetess [[Poulcheria]], whose teachings formed the bedrock of [[his church|The Canticle]]; and he easily rose to the rank of [[Radiant]].

When he came of age, Lucerius left seminary to join [[Tarmon Gellius]] in his company known as [[The Grey Companions]].  It was here he found purpose and brotherhood unlike anything he felt before; even his connection to [[The Gods]].  His devotion to [[The Grey Companions]] surpassed everything else.

!Innocentius Lucerius
Lucerius soon found himself in the foreign continent of [[Kellos]], far from his homeland.  [[The Grey Companions]] served as the vanguard for [[The Amoni Invasion]] of [[Kellos]], establishing civilization in an untamed wilderness.  It was here, among [[Kell]], [[Bairn]], [[Forana'loloKashira]], and [[Kombar'Ran]] that he found his faith wane.  He learned from alternative religions such as [[The Old Faith]], that there were other forces at play; that [[Humanity|Human]] owned its existence not just to [[The Sovereigns|Elysian]], but also to the entity known as [[Valouria]].

While he began to form his thoughts as early as 1812 [[IO]], the same year of [[Tarmon Gellius's|Tarmon Gellius]] death, he would not officially pen the words of [[The Birth Of Light And Truth]] until 6 years later in 1804 [[IO]].
[>img[images/gods/lucian.jpg]]

Lucian, daughter of [[Umwe]], is an [[Elysian]]; one of [[The Gods]] of [[Asha]].  To the [[Elves|Elf]] she is known simply as "vi", and is their divine creator.  She has the form of a beautiful female [[Elf]] with white wings, similar in appearance to her children the [[AstraKashira]].

It was Lucian who would commune frequently with [[Raime Wesewierë]], one of her most devout followers.  It was through her teachings that Raime resisted the temptation of [[Zezebazum]] allowing [[The Eternal Cycle]] to continue.

She frequently quarrels with her brother [[Qualok]] and father [[Umwe]] as their unwavering patience unnerves her.  Through inaction they allow injustice to fester.  This impulsive urge to set the world to order causes her to be one of the most meddling [[Gods|The Gods]] in mortal life.  It was Lucian, combined with her brothers [[Kombar]] and [[Xander]], who imprisoned [[Azarad-Ji]] after his vicious murder of [[Valouria]].

It was [[Lucian]] who was sent to subdue [[Azarad-Ji]] once more during [[The Second Age]] with [[The Spire Of Planes]].  It was [[ImoMahtara]], a foot soldier [[AstraKashira]] that struck the final blow for the battle and used [[The Spire Of Planes]] to vanquish [[Drelmor]].
[>img[images/characters/kellos/the-keep/deepwater/lysandra-jedaleon.jpg]]
{{quote{
//Grief taught me the lesson that ambition could not; that even the purest intentions can ignite a storm if left unchecked.//
''-Lysandra Jedaleon, reflecting on [[Elyra Nerenic]]''
}}}
[[Empress|Emperor]] Lysandra Jedaleon (816 [[AAP]] - 898 [[AAP]]) was a pivotal figure in the history of [[The Viridian Empire]]. Known to history as The Beloved, she was the first ruler of [[The Jedaleon Dynasty]] and a transformative monarch.  Rising from a middling background within [[The Magian Imperium]], she leveraged wit, foresight, and political cunning to claim the throne in a succession crisis following the death of [[Emperor]] [[Calvather Nerenic]].  Though not the most powerful [[Mage|Wizard]] of her age, her grasp of intrigue and her ability to rally both commoners and nobility secured her rule, eventually establishing the renowned [[Jedaleon Dynasty|The Jedaleon Dynasty]].

!Early Life
Lysandra was born in 829 [[AAP]] in the city of [[Deepwater]] to a minor noble branch of [[House Nerenic]].  While niece to [[Emperor]] [[Calvather Nerenic]], there was no path to the throne.  From an early age, she demonstrated uncommon intelligence and composure, traits that drew the attention of [[The Emperor|Calvather Nerenic]].  She entered [[The Magian Imperium]] as a young woman, not out of love for [[The Arcane Arts|Magic]], but because she recognized the political opportunities such a position afforded.  Her [[Magical Abilities|Wizardry]], while serviceable, were eclipsed by her keen mind, razor sharp intellect and strategic vision.  By the 850's she rose as a recognizable voice in [[Imperial|The Viridian Empire]] events, and [[The Emperor|Calvather Nerenic]], long widowed, saw in Lysandra a strength and wisdom he hoped his own young daughter might one day embody.

Summoning Lysandra, [[Calvather|Calvather Nerenic]] entrusted her with the care and education of his 8 year old daughter [[Elyra Nerenic]].  It had become known that [[Elyra|Elyra Nerenic]] possessed an extraordinary and dangerous gift, the uncontrolled spark of [[Wild Magic Sorcery|Wild Magic Bloodline]].  The child was comforted around Lysandra, which eased the [[Wild Magic]] surges she experienced.  For years, Lysandra acted as both tutor and steward, guiding [[Elyra|Elyra Nerenic]] with grace and affection.  She taught lessons in discipline, meditation, and the structure of [[Magic]] to attempt to control [[Elyra's|Elyra Nerenic]] power.  During this time, Lysandra learned the rhythms of [[Imperial|The Viridian Empire]] politics and the subtle arts of governance from [[her uncle|Calvather Nerenic]].

!Path To The Throne
In 862 [[AAP]], tragedy struck when [[Emperor]] [[Calvather Nerenic]] succumbed to illness.  Before his death, he decreed that his beloved niece Lysandra serve as guardian and regent until [[Elyra|Elyra Nerenic]] came of age.  Though some nobles questioned entrusting so much power to a young woman of lesser station, Lysandra's composure and [[The Emperor's|Calvather Nerenic]] confidence silenced dissent.

The loss of her father weighed heavily on [[Elyra|Elyra Nerenic]].  Her [[Wild Magic]] had always been erratic, but the strain of grief frayed her control even further.  Even trivial matters such as a servant's hesitation caused [[Elyra's|Elyra Nerenic]] temper to flare.  Her [[Wild Magic]] would surge living a living storm.  The room would fill with light and sound, or living fire.  Unbound [[Mana]] tore through stone and steel alike.  Servants refused to tend to her, and only Lysandra could comfort her.

Less than a year after [[her father's|Calvather Nerenic]] death, [[Elyra|Elyra Nerenic]] was no more.  Slighted by another child, [[Elyra Nerenic]] was said to erupt into a torrent of [[Magical|Magic]] chaos.  An explosion of force that melted stone and left nothing behind but silence and ash.  The healers and [[Clierics|Cleric]] of [[The Divine Order]] could find no trace of the child's soul, her essence wholly consumed by the explosion she had birthed.

With no heir remaining and [[The Viridian Empire]] desperate for unity, Lysandra was urged to assume the throne.  She did so reluctantly, wearing the crown not as a symbol of ambition but as an act of penance.  Thus began [[The Jedaleon Dynasty]], forged not of conquest, but of remorse.

!Her Rule
Lysandra’s intelligence shone in her ability to adapt to shifting circumstances. She surrounded herself with capable advisors, many of whom were drawn from outside traditional noble circles, valuing merit over lineage. This inclusivity, while controversial, ensured that her administration was one of the most competent in [[The Empire’s|The Viridian Empire]] history.
{{quote{
//Some believe that there is one correct way to enjoy tea.  This is simply a silly notion, as tea is a gift for all.  It is a tradition; a way of life.  Much like a successful life, a successful tea must embrace simplicity, patience, resilience, harmony, and balance.//
''-[[ElethaNori]] on the art of tea''
}}}

The Lysathira ("The Art Of Tea" in [[Elvish]]) is an [[Elvish|Elf]] tradition steeped in history, dating from [[The Third Age]] of [[The Sylvan Empire]].  It is a ceremonial way of preparing and drinking tea.  Beyond just serving and receiving tea, one of the main purposes of the tea ceremony is for guests to enjoy the hospitality of the host in an atmosphere distinct from the stress of everyday life.

The theology of tea dictates that the enjoyment of tea is not a solo act.  The full enjoyment of a tea requires the sharing of one's inner most feelings; it is more important to listen and find deeper meanings within the tea, and therefore [[The Mother|Valouria]].

!The Customs Of Tea
* When pouring tea for a guest, you must always serve the tea in the order in which you met them.

[>img[images/characters/baator/mad-maggie.jpg]]
Mad Maggie is a [[Hag]] who makes her lair in [[Fort Embermourne]] in [[Avernus]].  She is a powerful [[Avernian Warlord]] who has reign over a portion of [[Avernus]] that includes [[The Avernian Wastes]] and [[The Mold Thicket]].  She was once in a [[Coven|Hag Coven]] called [[The Coven Of The Bramble Root]] with [[Red Ruth]] and [[Old Ethel]], and assisted in corrupting [[The Bone Brambles]] by transporting it to [[Baator]].

She does not have affiliations with [[Shalekasha]], and seeks to bring [[Gargauth Souldrinker]] back to power.
[>img[images/characters/kellos/the-elven-lands/the-whispering-bog/maekhar-the-unliving.jpg]]
Maekhar Dezhul, [[Wyrmlord]], The Lord Of Ghosts, the Darkheart, Champion of [[The Battle Of Ish]], ended his mortal life over 2,000 years ago in a ritual to [[Urdlen]].  During this ritual, he became a [[Lich]], an undying creature capable of great [[Magic]] and power.  He resides deep within [[The Elvish Lands]], far from [[Human]] civilization in a dark swamp known as [[The Whispering Bog]].  Here, he conducts research on topics that amuse him such as the nature of [[The Abyss]] and [[The Eternal Cycle]].

He was one of [[The First Men]] of [[Kellos]], a group of [[Humans|Human]] that emerged in the region after the fall of [[The Sylvan Empire]].  Not much is known about his mortal life, other than he must have had a natural connection to [[Magic]] and had a [[Draconic Bloodline]].

The [[Elves|Elf]] of the area leave him be, as he is reclusive and currently not causing harm to the surrounding area.
[>img[images/characters/original-grey-companions/maerla.jpg]]
Mearla, (c. 1836 [[IO]] - Unknown) was a a [[Kell]], [[Stormsister]] born beneath thunder, [[Vezerga]] of [[The Stormcrows]], and one of the original [[Grey Companions|The Grey Companions]].  She was known for her unwavering bravery, fierceness, and boldness.  She wielded a great blade that once split a [[Jötnar]] skull, and a name that carried weight among the free tribes when she was alive.

!Early Years
She was raised to lead, her blood that from a long line of [[Vezergas|Vezerga]], however she earned her place by strength by slaying a [[Rockwyrm]] with her bare hands during [[Trona Lepes]] (The Rite Of Ascension).  [[The Stormcrows]] were known as stalward defenders of what is now [[The Stone Lands]].  In generations old skirmishes against [[The Cult Of The Dragon]] in [[The Dales]], Maerla kept the [[Reavers|The Cult Of The Dragon]] at bay.

!The Grey Companions
She was added to [[The Grey Companions]] by [[Proculus Attalia Varren]] when she showed valor defending an [[Amoni|The Amoni Republic]] supply chain from [[Kellish Reavers|The Cult Of The Dragon]]. 

It was in [[The Ashen Marches]], during the early years of [[Tarmon Gellius's|Tarmon Gellius]] [[landing in Kellos|The Amoni Invasion]], when [[Amoni|The High Republic]] legions were spread thin and rebellions flared like wildfires across the frontier. An [[Amoni|The High Republic]] supply column, two hundred strong (including wounded, engineers, and scouts) was ambushed in the choked ravines near [[Stonebreach Pass]] by [[Kellish Reavers|The Cult Of The Dragon]] loyal to [[The Grimm Tribe]], who despised the growing alliance between tribes such as [[The Stormcrows]] and [[The Republic|The High Republic]]. The ambush was swift and brutal, and when word reached the nearest outpost, [[Proculus Attalia Varren]]  himself led [[The Grey Companions]] to intervene, but they were too late.  The pass was choked with bodies, and only one soul remained to meet them.

Maerla Stormsister stood alone atop a crag of blackened stone, her sword broken, her shield shattered, her arms smeared in blood not her own. Around her lay a score of dead [[Reavers|The Cult Of The Dragon]], each killed not by precision, but raw fury and unyielding will. She had led a breakout charge to draw scatter their numbers, alone, and held the narrow pass for nearly an hour until the enemy routed or fell.
The military might of [[The Zynovum Arcanum]], a region of [[Kellos]] during the height of [[The High Republic]] of [[Amon]].  This group was comprised of Wizard-Knights, formidable in both the [[Arcane]] and Martial pursuits.  Ancient sources mark the Mage Guard as up to 1,000 strong, but modern scholars suggest the size was likely no more than 300.

The Mage Guard was most famously commanded by [[Fazar]].  Who was elected [[Praetor]] to battle the [[Orc]] tribes south of [[Kellos]].  Most famously, [[Fazar]] was named [[Praetor]] by [[Teldinath Dagon]] and [[The Assembly|The Amoni Assembly]] to hunt down and subdue [[Cyril Viridian]] in 9 [[IO]], when [[Cyril|Cyril Viridian]] ignored their orders and marched [[Vesna Zeuxis]] a contingent of [[Uskardeen]] refugees into [[The Waste]].
Although magic is not a staple of everyday life for most of the people of [[Asha]], it is not considered uncommon.  No one expects to see a mad sorceress running down the streets throwing fireballs, but maybe the local doctor is a wizard with lots of healing spells.  Most mages live relatively normal lives as teachers, entertainers or country “hedge wizards”.  There are a few who go out and get themselves caught up in adventures, become mercenaries or join militias.   Some enter into politics, as many are wealthy with high status. But that is uncommon because mages simply love the study and practice of their art.  And being that it is quite easy for a mage to make a living just about anywhere he goes just by performing magic (either for entertainment or service), most choose to stay in one place, sometimes never venturing far from home.

This is not to say that all mages are lily white with honest intentions, when wizards do get out of line it tends to be taken very seriously.  When magic is used to harm the innocent, or magical experimentation brings about disaster for a town: people get upset.  When a wizard creates problems with his magic (whether its accidental or not) that gets causes trouble in a town, the city guard will come after that wizard (if the lynch mob doesn’t get him first) right after they repair the damage.

In ages past, [[Cyril Viridian]] outlawed the use [[Magic]] and mages were hunted and killed in a war known as [[Azutan Nagyos]].  Since then, the law was amended and mages have once again come out into the open and have been productive members of society.  There are those who still harbor the historical [[Intolerance For Magic]], but those people are rare and far between - or keep their mouth shut.

To sum it up very simply, mages can fit into almost any aspect of society.  Common folk think of magic as a great skill that’s hard to learn and can do a lot of great things.  People won’t expect to see a mage every day but won’t be shocked or terrified when they do.  Most wizards are considered pleasant and the bad apples don’t ruin the bunch.
{{quote{
//"I swear by [[all the gods and goddesses|The Gods]], making them my witness, that I will carry out, according to my ability and judgment, this oath and this bond.

I will share my learning and practices with indentured pupils who have taken this oath, but to nobody else.

I will not claim my abilities to be a holy gift, or in any ways divine.

I will use my powers to the betterment of [[The Viridian Empire]], and the [[Emperor]], [[The Gods]] protect him.

Now if I carry out this oath, and break it not, may I gain for ever reputation among all men for my life and for my art; but if I transgress it and forswear myself, may the opposite befall me.

I solemnly take this oath, freely and on my honor."//
''-The Oath Of The Magian Imperium''
}}}

In [[Kellos]], the laws of [[The Viridian Empire]] require that those who practice [[Magic]] obtain a license from [[The Magian Imperium]].  This includes paying a fee, along with a drop of blood being collected and stored in a [[Sanguilacrum]].  This blood could then be used to track down errant uses of [[Magic]].

{{floatTableRight{
| [>img[images/file-icons/pdf-icon.jpg][documents/d&d5e/magic/asha-spellbook.pdf]] |
| [[Asha Spellbook|documents/d&d5e/magic/asha-spellbook.pdf]] |
}}}
There are three known sources of magic: [[Mana]], [[Spirit]], and [[Void|Void Magic]].  [[Mana]] fuels the [[Arcane]] spellcasting of [[Wizardry]] and [[Sorcery]].  [[Spirit]] is the source of [[Primal Magic|Primal Magic]] and [[Blood Magic]], and [[Void Magic]] can be harnessed by [[The Elder Gods]] or other powerful, immortal beings - as well as some [[Skalds|Skald]] who have begun to tap into the powers that created the universe.  Others harness [[Void Magic]] through [[Patronage|Patron]] to a powerful being in the form of [[Occultism]] and [[Divine Favor]].

| [[Wizardry]]<br>([[Arcane]]) |//[[Wizardry]] is obtainable by any who possess the fortitude for the intense study of the science of [[Mana]].  Its effects are generally large, flamboyant and visible in translucent runes, symbols and gestures.  [[Wizards|Wizardry]] require [[Spell Books|Spell Book]] and [[Arcane Foci|Arcane Focus]] to effectively cast and harness Magic, learning spells as one would learn a new skill.// |>|
|~|''Arcane Traditions:'' |[[Abjuration]] · [[Alkemancy]] · [[Conjuration]] · [[Cygimancy]] · [[Divination]] · [[Enchantment]] · [[Evocation]] · [[Glamour]] · [[Illusion]] · [[Meta Magic]] · [[Transmutation]] · [[Traveling]] · [[Runemancy]] |
|~|''Advanced Concepts:'' |[[Eldermancy]] · [[Eidolon]] · [[Mythal]] · [[Teleportation Circle]] |
|!|>|>|
| [[Sorcery]]<br>([[Arcane]]) |//One cannot become a [[Sorcerer|Sorcery]].  You are either born one, or you are not.  Those gifted with [[Sorcery]] are living conduits of [[Mana]], intuitively feeling the effects of Magic all around them.  Casting is done with sweeping body movements that can be described as beautiful; resemble dancing or martial arts.// |>|
|~|''Bloodlines:'' |[[Celestial|Celestial Bloodline]] · [[Demonic|Demonic Bloodline]] · [[Draconic|Draconic Bloodline]] · [[Dwarvish|Dwarvish Bloodline]] · [[Fey|Fey Bloodline]] · [[Wild|Wild Magic Bloodline]]|
|~|''Advanced Concepts:'' |[[Mythal]] · [[Enchantment]] · [[Heartstone]] |
|!|>|>|
| [[Blood Magic]] <br> ([[Spirit]]) |//[[Blood Magic]] is the name given to a suite of magical effects that can be achieved through the exploitation of the [[Spirit]] energy found within all flora and fauna.  While the rituals are easy enough for a laymen to follow, the effects are fickle the more complex the ritual and are taboo due to their need for the consumption of life and [[Spirit]].// |>|
|~|''Rituals:'' |[[Curses]] · [[Charms]] · [[Alchemy]] · [[Necromancy]] · [[Brujeria]] · [[Channeling]] · [[Hemomancy]] |
|~|''Advanced Concepts:'' |[[Corruption]] |
|!|>|>|
| [[Primal Magic]] <br> ([[Spirit]]) |//[[Primal Magic]] is harnessed through a natural connection with the [[Spirit]] of [[Valouria]].  Where [[Blood Magic]] consumes [[Spirit]], [[Primal Magic]] restores and replenishes it through tapping into the natural cycles that make life possible.  Those that practice [[Primal Magic]] are often called [[Druids|Druid]] or [[Shaman]].//|>|
|~|''Primal Paths:'' |[[Circle Of The Moon]] · [[Circle Of The Land]] · [[Circle Of Dreams]] · [[Circle Of Rot]] |
|~|''Primal Powers:'' |[[Winter]] · [[Summer]] · [[Spring]] · [[Autumn]] · [[Dawn]] · [[Dusk]] · [[Stars]] |
|~|''Advanced Concepts:'' |[[Leylines]] · [[Wild Shape]] · [[Faeratha]] · [[Dream Walking]] |
|!|>|>|
| [[Skaldic Magic]] <br> ([[Void|Void Magic]]) |//Some can train themselves to hear and comprehend the Magic inherent in the universe, called [[Void Magic]], which give [[The Elder Gods]] their power.  They understand that sound and song contain the same power that was weaved into the fabric of creation itself, and underpins the world in which they live.//|>|
|~|''Colleges:'' |[[College Of Whispers]] · [[College Of Valor]] · [[College Of Lore]] |
|~|''Advanced Concepts:'' |[[The Voice]] · [[Sniffing]] · [[Psionics]]|
|!|>|>|
| [[Divine Favor]] <br> ([[Patron]]) |//There are those who have earned the [[Patronage|Patron]] of one of the [[Elysians|Elysian]] or other divine being.  They gain favor from these [[Patrons|Patron]] for as long as they continue to walk the path prescribed by their [[Deity|The Gods]].  Their connection to their [[Patron]] gives them the ability to resurrect life and redirect the hearts and spirits of individuals.//|>|
|~|''Domains:'' |[[Life & Light]] · [[Knowledge & Fate]] · [[War & Protection]] · [[Forge & Tempest]]|
|~|''Advanced Concepts:'' |[[Paladin Oaths]] · [[Miracles]] · [[Religion]] · [[Resurrection]] |
|!|>|>|
| [[Occultism]] <br> ([[Patron]]) |[[The Gods]] are not the only [[Patrons|Patron]] in [[Asha]].  Where [[Divine Favor]] is akin to a bond, [[Occultism]] is a parasitic relationship; albeit at times a symbiotic one.  Either the power of an uncaring [[Patron]] is exploited, or a more active [[Patron]] gifts powers as long as their needs are met. Often these relationships are strained. |>|
|~|''Pacts:'' |[[Fey Pact]] · [[Fiend Pact]] · [[Elder Pact]] · [[Shadow Pact]] |
|~|''Advanced Concepts:'' |[[Invocations]] |

!Innate Magic
[[True Naming|True Name]] · [[Foretelling]] · [[Magic Resistance]] · [[Lucid Dreaming]] · [[Lorechant]] · [[Tuning]]

!Related Articles
[[The Weave]] · [[Mana]] · [[Mana Dead Zone]] · [[Linking]] · [[Time Manipulation]] · [[Umbramancy]] 

!Customs
* [[Dragonmark]] - the art of tattooing that has been perfected to a state in which [[Magic]] can be infused with the ink.  This grants powers to one who bears a [[Dragonmark]], however only the rich dare to afford them.
{{quote{
//To speak the words of Magius is not to command nature, but to converse with the cosmos itself.  Each syllable is a key, and the universe listens when the lock is turned correctly ''- [[Drakon Nhauxzor]], one of [[The Luminari]]''//
}}}

Magius is not an invented or created language, but rather the representation of the underlying blueprint of reality itself, discovered and harnessed by [[skilled practitioners|Wizardry]] of [[Magic]].  By uttering specific sounds, performing precise movements, and understanding the connections between them, [[Wizards|Wizardry]] manipulate [[Mana]] and [[The Weave]], the unseen threads that bind the fabric of existence.  Magius is not merely a tool but an ongoing mystery, a natural language woven into the cosmos, waiting to be uncovered through study and experimentation.  Words in Magius resonate with the natural order and serve as a bridges between thought and reality.  When spoken or written, they do not simply communicate ideas - they shape the world.

!History
The discovery of Magius was a slow and deliberate uncovering of the profound truths hidden within the natural world.  The initial discoveries were fragmentary, like isolated islands of knowledge in a vast, uncharted sea.  Early [[Wizards|Wizardry]] noted that certain vocalizations produced observable effects upon the world.  They meticulously recorded their findings, noting the effects of different sound combinations and the subtle shifts in the flow of [[Mana]].  Over generations, these observations were compiled and analyzed, revealing intricate patterns and relationships between sounds and movements.

Patterns began to emerge, and the building blocks of greater [[Magical|Magic]] structures were formed.  It became evident that [[Verbal]] and [[Somatic]] components were interdependent, and the Magius alphabet (known as [[Runic]]) emerged as a visualization of this relationship.

!The Nature Of Magius and Runic
Magius is thought to be infinite in scope, a universal lexicon that describes the very mechanics of existence.  Even the words that form the basis of [[Wizardry]]: Magius, [[Weave|The Weave]], [[Mana]], and [[Wizard|Wizardry]] are themselves vocalizations of Magius.

The alphabet of Magius, known as [[Runic]] is not merely a written script, but a representation of the [[Somatic]] gestures used in [[Wizardry]].  Each symbol pictographically describes a specific movement of the body or positioning of the mouth.  For example, the word "Magius" (May-gee-us मागियुस्) encapsulates both the verbal sound and its physical representation, uniting them into a single, powerful concept.

!Learning Magius
Learning Magius is a challenging and lifelong pursuit.  Years of dedicated study are required to master even the most basic principles.  Aspiring [[Wizards|Wizardry]] must first learn to attune themselves to [[The Weave]], to feel its subtle currents and rhythms.  Despite millennia of study, Magius remains only partially understood.  New "words" are discovered, unlocking new possibilities for interacting with the universe.  The language of Magius is thought to be infinite.


[>img[images/characters/kellos/the-stone-lands/magnus-zizorum.jpg]]

Magnus Zizorum (985 [[AAP]] - Current) is a [[Sorcerer|Sorcery]] and [[Warlock]] who operates within the region of [[The Stone Lands]] in [[The Viridian Empire]].  Bald and aged, Magnus is nonetheless a physically impressive man made all the more powerful-seeming by his considerable charisma, commanding voice, and determined manner.  While he rarely looks relaxed or at ease, he occasionally flashes an amused smile or more often a sneer.  His is equally powerful in both [[Sorcery]] and [[Blood Magic]], which shows upon his body; his eyes are red and bloodshot, and his skin grey and covered with dark black veins.  Often he uses incantations to hide this appearance, due to his vanity.

Magnus is driven and has little time for what he deems to be unimportant and insignificant such as politics.  He will stop at nothing in order to achieve his goals and get what he desires.  He sides with [[Azarad-Ji]] and [[Desecration]], not as a fanatic zealot but as a self proclaimed realist.  He sees the endgame in which the forces of [[Desecration]] need only succeed once, and defending the world from destruction can grow intensely tiring.  It's logic which makes him want to ensure there is a place of power for him when the world crumbles.

It was Magnus that used [[Blood Magic]] to restore the eyesight of [[Desini Orosco]] in order to curry favor with her and her younger sister, whom he was attempting to recruit in the backwater village of [[Wayfaire]].  The two girls ran off with him into his lair in the mountains, where it was the younger sister [[Lyla Orosco]] who first fell victim to his charms.  The two had a baby together, [[Erik Orosco|Erik Doorhaus]].  Magnus's plan all along was to use this baby as a sacrifice in a [[Blood Magic]] ritual to [[Urdlen]] in order to achieve immortality.  He failed due to the heroics of [[Desini Orosco]], who absconded with the baby never to return.  [[Lyla|Lyla Orosco]] unfortunately died in the ritual.

Desini sought [[The Grey Companions]] in the city of [[Brand]] for help.  They tracked down Magnus and killed him in 1009 [[AAP]], only for Magnus to mysteriously reappear in 1020 [[AAP]] and trap and kill [[The Grey Companions]] [[Rog]], [[Dargay Earthhammer]], [[Malden Bray]], [[Chandi]], and [[Sanders]] in a rift to [[The Shadowfell]] the village of [[Abermaw]].

Magnus has a second son [[Malochai Zizorum]] who appears to be a twin of his son [[Erik|Erik Doorhaus]].  His origin is a mystery.

In a confrontation with [[Desini Orosco]], Magnus was subdued and fitted with an [[Enchanted|Enchantment]] collar which prevents the wearer from using [[Sorcery|Sorcery]] and [[Wizardry]]; however he escaped with a flourish of [[Blood Magic]] and remains at large.
[>img[images/characters/baator/mahadi.jpg]]

Mahadi is an [[Incubus]] who owns [[The Wandering Emporium]] found in [[Avernus]] within the [[Plane|The Planes Of Existence]] of [[Baator]].

Outwardly, Mahadi presents himself as a charismatic and gracious host.  He makes each guest feel as though they're the most important person in all of [[The Planes Of Existence]], catering to their every whim and desire.  While he is equally cordial to all guests of [[The Wandering Emporium]], those entering his establishment fall under a special contract and therefore rank most highly in his esteem.
[[First Things First...]]
